reviewText: All, probably, read stories about brave knights who went down in vaults for fight with a dragon, overcoming traps and winning on the way against the whole hordes of monsters. And if you dream to be that knight, this game for you. Game narrates about history of knights who were wrecked on a hostile planet. You play for one of these knights and with colleagues you travel on vaults, winning on the way of monsters and solving puzzles to reach a kernel of this hostile planet. Certainly, in original state of Spiral Knights of very few people it will be necessary. It is game without plot, with incidentally generated levels, with crowds of enemies. Only I aim, games tamping of pockets by game currency and continuous search of the best equipment that it was possible to move to more difficult level is. Game on pilaf will hold on or not, everything depends on developers. Certainly, Three Rings Design everything provided it and constantly try to diversify game. First, players lay a hand to creation of levels. Secondly, regular large updatings in which are added new equipment, monsters, bosses, levels and it is a lot of that else. In the third, fascinating puzzles over which it is necessary to think. In four, players can influence game economy. If developers continue in the same spirit game the bigger success waits still, differently players will quickly lose to it interest. The first impression of game as from a usual unpretentious arcade, but after some hours of game you understand that tightens you this fascinating world. In this game everything depends on you and your equipment, after all strength of the real knight depends on ability of possession of the weapon and its jokes. It is game for those who loves browsers with monsters and puzzles. In this game it isn't necessary to turn gray in the days that to achieve something. Probably, the majority represent the knight with a sword in the right hand and a board in left or with a spear on a horse. But these knights except boards and swords can arm with the gun or a bomb and to carry amulets and bracelets, and the number of the most this weapon pleases with a variety. The attention is drawn by game in team, here it isn't necessary to compete because of game currency or resources as everything is distributed equally. Therefore players try to play is put, after all not to pass some moments without harmonious team work and mutual assistance. Game process looks quite attractively, you crumble packs of monsters, you fight with bosses, you plunder treasuries, you solve puzzles. Puzzles in this game deserve attention, they are very interesting, though aren't too difficult. But nevertheless, on pro-procession of two hours, game after all becomes boring. On the substance of Spiral Knights – qualitative arcadian RPG MMOG, beautiful and at first sight the extremely unusual behind which it is possible to spend some hours in day

reviewText:
So,  I recenly discovered that this game is on the verge of dying. Popular speculations believe it Nick Popovich, getting fired, but I believe this game is dying because of an innate amount of terrorist propaganda and 9/11 symbolism.

I first comtemplated this theory when joining my friends in the Roarmulus Twins boss raid. At first I was greeted with a spacious warehouse filled tothe brim with missiles. At first I thought we had been trapped in an ISIS warehouse, but our operatives briefed us that instead he had been deployed to infiltrate one of America's top secret missile bases.

Our team elimated eliminated those wretched American pigs without fail and we proceeded to the R&D centre of the base. We discovered  American had been secretly develope Gremlin super soldiers or known code A.S.S (Anti-Syrian-Services)

Out team struggled and we lost 2 great men, we said our praises to our fallen comrades, hoping Allah would have mercy on their souls. With our burning anger towards those disgusting American pigs burning greater than ever, we proceeded to the heart of the base.

To our bewilderment we discovered the most shocking and most unethical act we thought those damn American scum would pull of on us. They had weaponised the Twin Towers. We cautiously crept towards those two proud works of our enemies, and without notice lights on the tower's eyes started glowing red, like the eyes of an untrained beast, and it was our job to put it down.

[missing scene here]

After our courageous acts, genius tactics and the blessing of Allah, we felled the mechanical beasts. When the lights on their eyes flickered, then dimmed, then turned off, we knew we had won this day. Today was the day everyone would see us, as heroes, the day everyone would know that we were the ones who fought, tooth and nail for them so that they could see the beauty of the Cradle. Today, was the 11th of September, 2001.

Allahu Akbar.

reviewText:
This was one of my favorite games to play for a while and it got better once I put a little bit of money into it. However the sprite update ruined the game for me and I do not like the direction the game is heading.

Pre Sprite Update 9/10
It's very fun to explore and level up your weapons. The whole market and trading system was pretty good, especially if you're too lazy to get crafting materials yourself. To sum it up the whole thing was a fun experience for me. The only thing was the elevator costs. So if you run out of mist energy, you have to wait awhile for it to refill, but I guess that is the cost of it being Free-to-Play" right?

After Sprite Update 4/10
The big problem of this update was the heat nerf. So now it's a pain in the a$$ to level up your weapons and armour. The actual sprites aren't so bad themselves
date: you get a little extra power against enemies. Before the update I bought a elevator pass
recommended: so when the update came they removed elevator costs so they traded in my pass for a bunch of crystal energy and other helpful things. But that does not make up for the fact that it will take a lot longer for a new player to level up higher. They added "The Forge"
hoursPlayed: the new way of leveling up items

otherwise it will take you a long fụcking time.

Finishing comments:
I've played this game for a few years and it was mostly worth it. But the devs fụcked up the game and my money I put towards it was a waste. So if you are a new player and/or if you are starting the game

reviewText: Spiral Knights, whilst not a perfect experience was enjoyable if you were willing to ignore the assortment of problems the game has. To start the game is a great semi-top down shoot/beat em up which at times can be very challenging, the game play is pretty good, however what bothers me is how the game is handle i.e. updates which are basically flagrant cash grabs for sub-par cosmetics. Very few good updates have occured during my time playing, with many of them only their for getting new cosmetics, and probably the most enjoyable of missions is sadly DLC only. Had this Three Rings actually cared for their community this would be extremely good game, but sadly it just falls flat. If you're looking for a game like this try elsewhere first.

reviewText:
Yes you might be like looking at my time and that I am saying that this game is not recommended by me and you're like what the ♥♥♥♥ well I will tell you why.

Well when I began playing this game you will have to do alot of grinding to save up crowns in order to get recipes, materials, Crystal Energy in order to upgrade your gear it was ALOT of fun I used to play all day long as soon as I got home I would be playing Spiral Knights because of the excitement of getting stronger, meeting new people having fun together and do a little roleplay together etc.

It was possible to actually beat the game without spending any money cause as you can see there is alot of Free To Play games out there but they all will have their shop where you would add real money and purchase Items such as Team Fortress 2, Realm of the Mad God, Magicka: Wizard Wars and much more to be named and in one of the Spiral Knights update last year they made heating (leveling system for weapons/shields/armors etc) and crafting system much more difficult for your to be able to actually complete the game without spending any money and the thing with Spiral Knights is that when you start it okay, if you fall in love with it you will continue, you will make friends, you will make progress and when you do, you will not wanna quit because you've created bonds with people in the game which means that u will wanna go all the way to the end which means you will at some point waste money on the game and when you finish the game you might wanna add the people on Steam BUT HEY!! they might be WEBSITE USERS you know what that means you can't add all your friends on Steam to easily to contact them when you want, there is a possibility to add them on Skype, Facebook etc but most of them wont have that type of Social Media which will force you to KEEP playing the game to still be friends with them and if you do keep playing that game you will wanna continue becoming stronger which means more money wasting and if you're desperate to quit the game you're gonna have a HARD TIME it was soo difficult for me to quit the game because of all the friends I had on that game and insane progress I had but this will ruin your life quitting this game is like quitting smoking but it may be easy for others but it certainly was difficult for ME!!

reviewText:
-Spiral Knight is like old-series of top down Zelda arcade shooter/hack n slash genre, you get to slice or blast bushes with either your melees or guns!

So you start your GAMEPLAY with many quest that keeps giving you gears and gears and gears until you reach a point of free-roam, where you see all these cool gears and shiets you get to craft and BRING THEM ALONG your whole journey as you upgrade them and level yourselves.
Yes, levels/stats/powers/ranks are based of from your gears, and experience in combat but not too deep in aspect.

ENEMIES DESIGNS are very creative, you get slimes that just refuses to go away, and lil midgets that dodges more smarter than a goblin in those normal ♥♥♥♥♥♥ MMOs, turrets that shoots heat-seeking rockets, when these things are stacked together and provoked, you'll see danmaku everywhere!
And bosses! who just have high absurd amount of hp againts your dodgingXkiting skills while using their awesome graphical skills that makes you go tripping balls.

CONTROLS allows hybrid maneuver where you can use WASD and your mouse in shooting/slashing, spacebar to switch your weapon. Many players have notice the [Backstrafe] speed which are slowed, and decided to use the <^>v arrow movement keys instead to make sure they never move backward, all in order to maintain their speed, with no mouse? you get auto-aiming system that assist in your gunning/slashing. but you could use BOTH controls system.

Cons:
Theres none really, market inflation are solely design on popular items cause they're rare drops in grinding dungeon stage runs, since GEAR is mostly everything in your pace for this game.
Lag makes your progress harder in dodging element, npc AI have the upper hand on this matter so don't think about abusing it.
Grind seems tiring still so don't go over-dedicated for this game, just play it with your friends once in a while to enjoy the eb of wind.

-get carried by max gear players throughout the elevator to the end of an arcade.
10/10 would go sightseeing for more again while spamming ressurection sparks.

reviewText:
I'll start with the pros and move to the cons, as optimism is a virtue.

+Helpful, patient admins.
+Ingame soundtrack that has its own peculiar flair. It can be somewhat of an acquired taste, but overall the soundtrack is gud.
+Really neat skyboxes. Though said skyboxes will turn your computer into a toaster if you have a crap-tier AMD graphics card.
+Chibi artstyle. I've never been really scared by any of the enemies due to this, though a few have their creepy side, such as the spectral felines you'll find in haunted zones.
+The community (ingame and on the official Spiral Knights Forums) is generally welcoming and helpful, though there are a few loud complaints about various things at times. Can hold decent, respectable conversations with other players.
+Smooth character control using the mouse.
+Makes you not want to kill the rare enemies that can occasionally drop special loot. This is something I don't see often, as it turns the killing-things cash-grab into a this thing doesn't hurt you; are you really gonna kill it?" scenario.
+Wide variety of armor and weaponry to create
date: although you have to work for it.\n+Every single obtainable item save for armor accessories has its own peculiar flavor text. These can be fun for trivia enthusiasts.\n+The developers will occasionally take ideas from the official forums pages and incorporate them into the game
recommended: though this can be a rare occurrence.\n+Lots of alliteration and a few puns here and there. Mostly in the names of different dungeons and the flavor texts of certain items.\n+The storyline is fragmented
hoursPlayed: but the shards of its canon are dynamic. Spaceflight from a genocidal war
voteText: a mysterious crash-landing on a celestial body of machinery and nature
helpfulPercent: an oligarchal dictatorship bent to its rulers' own twisted design
votesHelpful: a tortured
votesTotal: fiery Duke of a smoldering kingdom
votesFunny:
forever believing his realm is under siege...all of this is part of the world the player characters live in.
+Sentient jelly cubes with mustaches
+helicopter birds
+tree physics have yet to make any sense
commentsCount:
as the leaves aren't attached to the trunk. good stuff.
+demons throw office supplies at you. Only the disgruntled overtime-workers use pitchforks.
+I'm pretty sure that putting a rocket engine on a war-hammer is the greatest achievement weaponry has to offer.

Now for the cons.
-Development of the game has slowed to a crawl. Although the major updates are impressive
column16: they come few and far between
column17: and as such there hasn't been much to accomplish once endgame is reached. This is a major contention with players who lack a certain amount of patience.\n-Promotional "costume" items are produced more often than game updates. This
column18: too
column19: leads to negative feelings toward the developers
column20: as the costume items can only be acquired using real-world funds. Though it does lead to a huge variety of player costumes and personalized outfits. I haven't seen a single other player that dresses their character the same as mine.\n-Many of the weapons have a certain niche in the game
column21: but there is a significant quality fluctuation when it comes to how well the small group of most-effective weapons function as opposed to the great variety of others.\n-Few money-making stages. There is one particular endgame dungeon that is the most effective way to earn ingame currency sans trading
column22: but as there are no other stages to rival its payout
column23:
playing the dungeon can become increasingly repetitive.
-The comment sections on Steam for most of the promotional costume updates are a veritable maelstrom of angry players. Being a repeatedly-returning player requires extraordinary patience.
-PvP can be difficult unless you're extremely good at it.

Overall
column24: if you play the game without expecting much new content to be released in a set period of time
column25: it's a good 8/10. For those of you with less patience with the dev team
column26:
probably not the game for you.

reviewText: Spiral Knights is a different type of RPG. You are a small knight who has crash landed on a strange planet and must get to safety. Once that is done you go through certain missions and delve into the clockworks, a massive underground mix of levels that are ever-changing. I have almost 700 hours into Spiral Knights because it was extremely intriguing and I would play 12 hours without even realizing it. However, the lack of content being added is saddening, especially when we get constant prize boxes" for every 10 dollars we spend with our hard-earned money. Besides that point it can be extremely hard to level up your gear.  Going from Tier 1 gear to Tier 5 took almost 400 hours alone. However
date: this was before the missions gave you a free set of recipes and crafting orbs. The crafting orbs were what replaced Energy in crafting. Energy was about 500x harder to get.\nThis game is VERY good with a group of friends (4 preferably) since the drops chances are higher and everyone gets their own loot. I do recommend this game because besides all the weak points
recommended: it is still very fun to slash

reviewText: The game is a classic free to play. Starts with a single player tutorial and then sends you to a city with all the other people playing online. The game itself consists of three tiers, each unlocked by crafting better gear to your knight. If you decide to buy energy with real money, you'll be getting better gear and unlocking tiers much faster, but it's still completely possible to unlock all tiers in reasonable amount of time by not using money. A part of the game reminds me of Team Fortress 2. It features crafting and trading which add to the variety of the game. You can craft gear that is strong against certain types of enemies to make beating certain boss stages easier. Overall, the game is very rewarding and fun if you put time to learn and play it.

reviewText:
Spiral Knights: a game that has certian charms from an explorer to a competitive player's point of view. I for one, am a collector, though only about 1/5th of the time through the (almost) 2 years playing this game.

Since the start, the game was sort of hard to grasp for FTPs who like to explore the depths and missions in the game, due to the mist limit going on. Nowadays though since August 8th, 2013, with the Battle Sprite release, more and more players could play without a toll limit. They have events and items on sale, sure, yet you won't need to participate in them if you don't want to. For those of you that are though, just remember you're very kind by helping them with developing more game features and helping out any problems that need to be fixed.

There's plenty of features to go through in the game without events as it's going on: Player vs player with either team vs team capping with your own selected gear and weapons for the tier in Lockdown, or a 3D bomberman styled way to battle with bombs given out, either free-for-all or team vs team in Blast Network. There's also ways to hang around with friends and socializing with new ones as you play through the game. Lastly, the biggest feature of them all, is exploring and either helping out or solo throughout the depths of the Cradle. Many monsters currently, and eventually appearing along the way, will be a task to fight on normal, advanced, or elite mode (I personally almost ALWAYS do elite mode nowadays). You may overcome obstacles on the way, though if you need help it's not too bad to call for some friends or guildmates.

By visual wise, I have to say: it's very artistic and charming in a way. The effects are very good and reminds me pretty much of Bomberman people with the players/NPCs (hence the mentioning of Blast network), who can dress up and wear gear that isn't just for bombing overall (You can use gear that goes along with being a swordsman, bomber, gunner, or a mix between).

There's a community of knights to talk with, in game and out game, either meeting up or talking in the Forums on the website, which tells about what's going on lately. This MMORPG bases mostly around communication most of the time, either by a normal player or a Game Master. Don't take others opinions too personally (such as the biggest topics using Auto-Target
recommended:
in the game"): Do what you feel is right and play the game like you want; Just don't go too far though by being too rude with other people please. Fighting negatives with negatives won't result with the best result.

www.spiralknights.com

Anyways

reviewText:
PROS
-It's a really cute game with a nice art style.
-Worth playing for a while.
-Not as P2W as when it first came out.

CONS
-The world is called Cradle and it has different layers to it, down to the core. The world and setting has potential, but the dungeon system gets repetative after a bit. It would be much better if it was like other MMORPGs, where there's a vast world to explore.
-There's a microtrasaction item (usually a box and key) that comes out every so often. It unlocks an item that customizes your character. It's similar to gambling in CSGO and TF2. I've never bought it before. The only problem is that not much development is put into the game and seeing that that's the only thing that gets updated month after month is disappointing.
-There's no way to move the camera and jump.

FINAL NOTES
-It's not for everyone though. I wanted to play it with multiple friends over the years and many of them immediately refused to play based off the pictures.
-I hope this game gets remade because I'd love to see a better version of it. It has potential. Add in jumping, a moveable camera that's also not so far out, a vast world rather than dungeons, skills, classes, races, more towns, jetpacks, things to do other than fighting, etc., and I think a lot of people would enjoy it.

reviewText:
Here's my opinion about SK:

PROS:

- Great intro, one of the best I've seen so far.
- The art style in this game is really good and unique. It's like a combination between Legend of Zelda and Chibi.
- Great, atmospheric music.
- Solid gameplay.
- Friendly community.
- Shadow Lairs.
- Intriguing story. (Can't wait for the other rank missions!)
- Can be really fun when playing with friends.
- It is indeed a F2P. You can obtain most of the weapons and the equipment and even cosmetics by paying no money. But it'll get harder. Trust me, it will.

CONS:

- After you become a Vanguard, things can get pretty dull.
- Game encourages you to grind. And by that, I mean a LOT of grinding.
- Connection problems. (Note: if you're from Australia or somewhere in Asia, expect a lot of trouble playing this game.)
- Can sometimes get boring.
- Not much activity when it comes to content.
- Price boxes. A CRAP-TON of Costume price boxes.
- SEGA. Crap.

FINAL VERDICT:

I'll give this game a 8.5/10.
It's not a flawless gem, but it's a solid game that can bring you lots of joy.
And while I don't really play SK that much nowadays like I once did before (problably it has to do with the lack of content and school, of course), I can say that Spiral Knights has a special place in my heart.
Met lots of great people, had tons of fun, joined a great guild (League of Gunners) and so on.

So yeah, that's pretty much my opinion about it.
I know it's not really detailed, but whatever.

Thank you for reading!

Yours truly,
Mordekai the Summoner (Siliuser in SK)

P.S: To all of my friends I've met in SK and are reading this,
Thank you and love you all, fellas :3

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

UPDATE: 13th of April, 2016 (I know, a bit late announcing this news.)

Spiral Knights has now been bought by Gray Havens (a company formed by former employers of OOO). Spiral Knights has been finally released from the greedy clutches of SEGA.

Let's hope for the best for Gray Havens and may them bring this once fun game back to it's former glory.

We are counting on you, Gray Havens!
voteText: 6 of 8 people (75%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
I would really like to be able to promote this game, but I can't. If it was about 2+ years ago I could, but that is not the case.

First thing, do not be mislead by my amount of hours played. I started SK before it was brought to Steam, and refused to link my main account to my Steam account due to perpetual connectivity issues between the two. I have more hours logged on SK than I have on Terraria and Mincraft combined.

They have changed the tutorial area from when I started, it is admittedly much better now. Has a minor storyline and teaches you how to use your various abilities. The game is much more approachable for newbies. Which is a definite plus. The removal of the energy system to do levels also means that newbies aren't restricted to 10 floors at max before they have to quit for about 24 hours (or pay money). That is all definite pluses.

The issues start about mid-tier, or 3-star gear. 3-star fire crystals and alchemy orbs are incredibly hard to find. Too early and you get 2-star stuff, if you do the boss areas odds are you will get 4-star stuff... and you don't get the recipe to downgrade the 4-star fire crystals to 3-star until AFTER a mision that requires you to level up 3-star gear enough to be in full 4-star gear. This is a minor setback, the big setback is high tier equipment. You need 5-star alchemy orbs and fire crystals for that, and unlike earlier tiers you can not downgrade higher crystals to make them. To fully level a single piece of 5-star equipment is going to cost you 453 fire crystals... or about 50 runs of the boss mission. You have at minimum a shield, 2 weapons, armor, and helmet, at maximum 2 more weapons. So that is a minimum of 250 boss mission runs, or 350 at maximum. And that is just for your starting set of gear.

But they don't want you to grind all that... they want you to buy the crystals. 50 5-star fire crystals costs 700 energy (cash shop currency), which is about 10-12 runs of the boss mission I mentioned, converting in game currency to cash shop currency (via a player run market). AKA NOT CHEAP!

They introduced pets at one point, reworking the mineral system (which originally were used to help influence the dungeons and get you some easy currency as well) into a way to feed and level the pets. There are 3 color pets: red, purple, and yellow. There are 5 colored minerals... 2 of which, blue and green, have absolutely zero use.

There are floors that are just horribly annoying to do, too high difficulty for too little payout. They're nice to experience, but a lot of groups will actively avoid them, to the point of waiting at the elevator at the end of a floor for 10 minutes to avoid such bad floors. Some floors, are amazingly fun. A lot of people hate Candlestick Keep, where an immortal ghost chases you, but I find them fun. Arenas are a blast, along with various other areas. But in comparison you can get Treasure Vaults... which are junk ironically, Compounds that are full of minis and are incredibly annoying, or Fiend floors... which a lot of people despise.

The last constantly available boss was introduced well over 2 years ago. There are minor bosses you can fight once for daily missions, but actual bosses you can just decide to go fight there has not been a new one in ages. There has been more gear added, but it is mostly reskins of other weapons with stat changes. And its hard to level due to the incredibly annoying fire crystal system.

PVP is even worse, it is dominated by people that have quite literally dropped $100s into the game by now. They have the best gear possible, my gear is high end (and I can do fairly well against them) but their stuff puts mine to shame, for the casual player you are just going to get beaten into the ground repeatedly. In addition to that if you don't have accessory slots (cash shop only!) than you are going to be at an even bigger disadvantage as everybody runs with health booster accessories.

On a sadder note, the game is dying. It started when the chief developer left, and now various other devs have as well. At one point it was not uncommon to see a dozen instances of the town going. For one event my guild saw over 70 instances running. Now you are lucky to get 3, and none of them are showing as full.

I really, REALLY want to be able to recommend this game... but I can't, not anymore. I love the art style, it is unique and cute and colorful. I love the music, Candlestick Keep has incredibly creepy but whimsical sounding music, the Wildwoods has beautifully fitting music for how its designed. I greatly like the atmosphere of the game, especially some of the areas created during the game's prime. The Wildwoods look amazing, as much as I dislike Compounds they look fantastic, and the Void is nicely threatening. The combat is fairly balanced in PVE until you hit high end. But I still can't recommend the game. Too many things have changed that just make it not player friendly anymore, and it shows.

Edit: And the game just got bought from Sega by a company called Grey Havens. Hopefully it will be good for the game, but it might be too little too late, only time will tell on that one.

reviewText: This game is amazing, trust me, I've played it since 2011. I've gone through hard times, and good times. This game is a bit harder on Veterans now, and rewards new players with many free things, which I don't find fair, but that's not my decision to make. If you don't have this game, you need it. If you love MMO's, get it, RPG's, get it. This game is a must have for a fan of either of those. There are many different armors to use, from using swords, to guns, to bombs, and even some event weapons. The costumes are amazingly designed, and playing with the right people can lead to domination.\nThe DLC, Operation Crimson Hammer, is also amazing. It provides a new boss, new missions, and exclusive weapons. I've played since 2011 and still haven't gotten all of the exclusive items from this. Because everything in the DLC is a challenge, or a cake walk.\nEverything in this game depends on your gear, play your cards right, and you can win almost anything.

reviewText:
Been playing this game for a very, very long time. I got it near when it just released, and I was very impressed and excited about it. However, since I can't give numeral or decimal ratings, I have to choose what I think of the game now: I just can't recommend it. I'll tell you why my love has been watered down as we go.

You and many other robotic knights crashed on a mysterious planet. This is no ordinary planet; the massive underground is filled with massive machines and gears that are constantly shifting levels. It's sometimes gloomy, sometimes cheery. It is inhabited with many monsters and gremlins who don't want you to explore. This place is called the Clockworks. In its center is your only hope of escape: the energy from the core.

GAMEPLAY

Newbies get to customize their character with various cosmetic armors and ascessories. You can change your knight's color, which affects your eye color and any parts of armors that allow change. You can also change their height.

By default you start with Proto gear, which includes an armor (this covers your body), a helmet, a shield, and two weapons: the Proto Sword and Proto Gun. You are taken through a tutorial that teaches you how to kill meanies and the beginning of your story. Following the tutorial are beginner missions with AI companions to give you a taste of the game and its story before you go on your own. These missions are pretty easy to do and reward you with more weapons to help you on your journey. At the end, you are taken to Haven and you get the Proto Bomb, which is the last type of weapon (swords, guns, and bombs). Haven is located at the surface and is where the knights research and train.

More missions can be done later when you are ready. These too will give you rewards. Complete a set of missions to be ranked up and move on to the next set. Ranks allow you to use better gear. Gear is ranked in stars like a movie would be rated. Most weapons can be upgraded to higher levels. Some ranks require you to have a full set of gear of a certain rank for you to continue to the next and to allow you to go down more tiers. Tiers are chunks of depths with sharp difficulty turns. There are 3 tiers in all. Missions can be replayed again and again as much as you want. You can also independantly delve down the clockworks.

There's two currencies in this game (I know what you're thinking): Crowns and energy. Crowns is earned in the Clockworks or by selling things. You use them to buy equipment from shops or you can trade them for energy. Energy is used mainly for reviving yourself if you die or for buying things in the Supply Depot. The Supply Depot is where you get to look at all the things you cannot get because you got no $$$ in your wallet. Energy can be traded for crowns and bought with real money (mhm, you see the picture now).

You can delve the clockworks solo or with 4 player co-op. To beat each level, you have to reach the elevator at the end of each level, which you can use to either continue going down or go back up. There's many areas to explore each level, and you can find materials to alchemize" new weapons or upgrade weapons. You only have one emergency revive
date: so be careful! You can buy sparks of life to revive you again if you need to with energy
recommended: which are available in the Supply Depot to buy. Sometimes you will run into a set of levels with a boss at the end. You will seldom run into the same level twice
hoursPlayed: as the levels change constantly at set times. The elevators give you a hint on the type of level it will be by the picture and color of the picture displayed on the screen on it. For example
voteText: a haunted fortress themed level would be a castle tower with either purple or red. Purple would be a little generic
helpfulPercent: and red will usually mean the Scarlet Fortress levels. Further information on the level ahead is given to you when you go down
votesHelpful: such as the name of the "series" (I call more specific themed places like the Scarlet Fortress [a haunted
votesTotal:
castle-like level] a series) and an area name (Firestorm Citadel: Smouldering Steps).

Near the end of the game comes the Shadow Lairs. The Shadow Lairs require a Shadow Key to enter. One key grants access for everyone in the party. These are boss levels with massive difficulty changes that make even the beginner's boss a challenge for a full party of 5 star players. On top of that are more powerful monsters and enhanced bosses. There's one for each boss. Each Shadow Lair opens the core little by little.

PvP is also a thing here. In the coliseum
votesFunny: you can pay 200 crowns (which is extremely cheap for most players) to play Lockdown or Blast Network. In Lockdown

reviewText:
This game is really great. Lots of fun, lots of weapons, lots of enemies, lots of different game styles to choose from.
This games follows the rule of 3. There are 3 types of weapons (sword, gun, bomb) to choose from. 3 types of damage, 6 families of enemies. Each family deals a different kind of damage, each family has different damage weaknesses and resistances. There are also 3 tiers to the game, with the difficulty increasing with each tier.
Spiral Knights also has some RPG mechanics with a twist: Instead of leveling up your character you level up your equipment. Once your stuff reach a certain level you can upgrade them to get better stuff.
The game is free and never forces you to pay, but you can always buy one of the energy packs if you feel like you're advancing too slow.
All armors and helmets can be customized with accessories earned throughout the game.
With Halloween, Christmas and anniversary events every year the game still sees new content from time to time and keeps a fresh feeling.

P.S.
I've been playing this game for 2 years now and I don't intend to stop.

reviewText: Spiral Knights is an all around good game. It's got stunning graphics, and the cartoony vibe fits it well. Combat is pretty solid, with loads of custimization and what not. Not that many microtranscations, and they're only for DLC or extra crowns (in game currency) or crystal energy (I believe crafting item). Colors are pretty nice too. Performance runs very well, with only a few chugs or hiccups here and there. Community is decent at kindness, but don't expect them to be throwing crowns at your face if you're begging (unless they're really nice). Guilds are also loads of fun. Storyline is probably interesting but I don't pay much mind to it.\n\nSpiral Knights, gets an 8/10.

reviewText: Very simple and easy to learn game. However, I found this simplicity to give it a lack of depth which made it boring after a while, but I always tend to get bored with mmo's after a while. The later introduction of Battle Sprites somewhat emulates the class systems of traditional mmo's. This is a good thing, I think. Mmo veterans expect at least something resembling a class system. Newbies should be introduced to this as soon as possible, as mmo's that don't have it are the exceptions. And it was good for the game itself to add much-needed depth. The amount of grinding required to fully level your Sprite, unfortunately, is ridiculous. Feels like a Korean mmo in that respect. The problem of a free-to-play game economy was handled well by making the cash shop currency purchasable with ingame currency, and shop currency required for crafting and adventuring. Overall, however, I find the most attractive part of this game to be its visual style.

reviewText: What if Zelda and Diablo had a love child...? Well, OK, that's probably not the most apt comparison to make, but it's close, I'd wager.\nPlease note that this game isn't really everyone's cup of tea. You'll either love it to death or wonder why your friends do. Adventures in the Clockworks can get a bit repetitive, but the PvP is sure to make up for that. And since it's a free-to-play game, there's absolutely no harm in just giving in to your whims and giving it a go if it strikes your fancy. You got nothing to lose, but weeks of fun-filled playing time to gain.

reviewText:
This game has many things going for it:
+ NotPoke- Battle Sprites
+ A decent in-game community
+ A level-up system based around only your equipment
+ Mostly randomized levels
+ Loads and loads of guns

This game has many things going against it:
- Somewhat empty instances
- Leveling equipment is almost entirely RNG
- Enemies can see you before you see them
- Loads of mid-endgame grinding
- Fiends

Now let's list the cons.

reviewText:
A great dungeon crawler game with tons of loot and adventurous levels.
If you do not like to go down in the Clockworks, you can just hang around in Haven meeting friends, or what ever you feel like doing.

There are a bunch of different branches of items you can have. You can have a sword that launches a way a fiery wall of explosions, or the same with ice instead. Why not grab a sword that incinerates everything around you? Or a bomb that spawns a rabid creature? Or a gun that shoots shadow orbs or razor sharp needles? It's up to you what way you want to go!

Same thing goes for the armor. There are tons of different armors. Everything from Cat looking armors to big heavy looking armors. All comes with different attributes.
You can change the armors' appearance by adding different accessories to it. Shadow bombs, shining tiaras, icy wings, fiery tails, you name it!

Note: This game takes a lot of time after you reach 3(star) items. You will need to find Orbs of alchemy which can take for ever to find. Or you can just buy them with the money you find in the game. Or in real life money, which will be the fastest.

Conclusion: If you like delving down in a huge world of adventure and loot, this is the game for you!

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Spiral knights is an MMO-dungeon crawler, unlike most MMO's that I play, This game suggests you play public games (but I just found the option that lets me solo! Thank you for letting me play my own way Spiral Knights). Additionally it automatically activates your microphone (I found out to my dismay on my second run, after I had been idly chatting with a friend on skype… and hearing an echo of my voice.)
-Detailed breakdown review-
Story:  From the state of the game, you get to customize your Spiral Knight, change his/her helmet make adjustments to the color, and then maybe throw on a few accessories. Once you’re finished you perform various tasks around camp to get things running again.

Game Play: You play the game like a dungeon crawler, you can also choose between three different control configurations. I chose to use the keyboard and mouse; the controls seem very straightforward and natural to me. You can switch between different weapons once you buy them later in the game; you start the game out with a pistol and a sword. No complaint I see no need for any other weapons.
Hopefully I don’t need to spell it out more about how the combat works, you shoot from far away with the pistol, you hit them with your sword in melee range, you block stuff with your shield, and you also have bombs that you can drop. You can also unlock, buy, and make new weapons and armor.
At rank 3 you start to be informed about the different types of gear you can wear. Since it’s an MMO, I assume this will play a larger role in the game further on. At the time that I am writing this review, I reached Shadow gear (which the game so kindly provided for me as I continued down the main story line. As long as the game doesn’t force me to spend real money, I’m okay with the gear based structure for this game.

Achievements: A majority of the achievements require collection of X amount of gear. There are a lot of hidden achievements that I will need to research once I get to be a higher level. Although I suspect that the game will eventually force me to team up with other players… and then let the ugly pugging commence. (Sorry, for those who don’t know: I really hate playing with people I don’t know.)
Basically, my impression is that the achievements reflect the amount of time you’ve spent playing the game. I was about a third of my way through the story, and I had about a third of the achievements in the game.

Price: Ah ha! This game is a Free to play! You have no real excuse for not trying it at least once. Since the game can be soloed (at least to where I’m at, one third complete) I think you can get a decent amount of entertainment out of the game, if you like dungeon crawlers, and a really simple easy game to pick up.

Conclusion: There really isn’t much reason to say “don’t get this game” especially since it’s free. I keep waiting for the point in the game where it says “HA! To be continued! Now pay us money just like you did the Arcade machine when you were little!” Nothing like that yet, so regardless, I feel I’ve gotten a fair amount of entertainment out of a game I didn’t buy.
No complaints, I’m enjoying the game still. (but I will always grind before I ever spend real money inside a game of any kind.)

reviewText:
Spiral Knights.....what have you turned into. Spiral Knights is a top-down, 2.5D (Can you call it 2.5D? Maybe it's more 3D than anything...) P2P Er I mean *Cough* F2P MMORPG where you run around and kick some monster butt like you did back in the days of the SNES with Legend of Zelda...but with a much better combat system (you would think). Lets start with the basics.
(Read farther if you please. Basic Synopsis- Casual gamer=SK is a good choice. Want more polish? Keep looking.
1; Graphics 7.5/10
Not exactly the greatest but not the worst either. What really makes this game so inviting is it's art style which is btw AMAZING! Everything looks awesome even though textures, models, and shading aren't top notch.
2; Community ?/?
I never really had anything to do with the community...maybe played every once 'n a while with strangers but I never really traded with anyone and that crap. Maybe someone else could answer that for you Mr/Ms viewer of my review (Really? I had to break the 4th wall?)
3; Soundtrack/SoundEffects 8/10
The sound track is really good. It has this feel of going on an adventure and discovering things like what a game like this should be. Every level has a nice theme that plays well with it, from volcanic forests to frozen devilite business offices to a ruin full of slimes. The sound effects are good too. Not much else to say for the sounds.
4;Leveling system.... Doesn't even need a rating....
First off, WHY DOES TAKE ME A YEAR JUST SO I CAN GO UP ONE GOD DARN RANK!?!?!? Before that I was zipping through the ranks like it was nothing! Then I got stuck trying to get to 4*, and I had to play for what like ages just so i could get my 5* armor.  I'm not saying that having to work to get to your rank is bad, but they way it has been implemented in this present edition of SK is ridiculous. Before (I'm sure most of you already know this who have been reading the reviews for hours now) the game had you collect heat (exp) that leveled up you're gear. What happened when it capped? IT LEVELED UP! WOW! IT CAN LEVEL UP! What happens now? You cap...and have to play for another 3 months just so you can get some stupid fire cyrstals to level up your gear BUT WAIT THERE'S MORE! NOT ONLY DO YOU HAVE TO GRIND FOREVER, YOU HAVE A CHANCE TO FAIL IN THE FORGE AND HAVE TO DO IT ALL OVER AGAIN! Isn't that just the sweetest thing ever.....NO! And the only thing you can do to make it work is have so much fire crystals for a 100% chance rate of working. I hate it so much. Oh and if you think I'm lying about spending months leveling up you just wait until you're Knight Elite...you just wait.
5; Gameplay 8/10
The gameplay is pretty solid. Basic 123 slash with pistol and a choice of using an explosive (which are overpowered if used with the right loadout). You can dogde and shield bash and defend and is relativley solid. Now, don't get GAMEPLAY confused with Difficulty." In reality

reviewText:
Hmm...Well, umm...

I like Spiral Knights, To keep this as short as I can because I'm sure your busy, this is the one MMO that clicked. Mabinogi is nice and WoW is fine while DC Universe Online gives you too much too soon, Spiral Knights keeps be coming back.

Firstly, I love the art style. It looks wonderful. Every weapon might seem a little 'fisher price' for others tastes but there's the extra details on them to give them a battle-worn feel. Plus, there's a clear progression in how each equipment changes as it upgrades. It's like Pokemon and it's satisfying.

The world seems vast and enjoyable that I think Three Rings have barely scratched the surface of. The idea of a world that is an ever changing dungeon is a pleasing idea to me. Especially the idea of you being some combination of fighter and miner. Digdug would crap himself trying to get through some of the monsters in this game.

The combat is a sort of top-down dungeon crawler. If you've ever played Alien Swam, it should be familiar. The interesting thing is the weapon choices. While you have to have a shield, you can choose to fill your two weapon slots with swords, pistols and bombs. Swords are the middle ground, offering a decent amount of damage but you need to be right up close to the baddies. Bombs take the longest to get up but offer the ability to drop and then run, keeping you out of the way of damage. Pistols are weaker but they allow for far more range with your attacks, keeping distance between you and your target. On top of that, each weapon has a special damage type that could either cause more or less damage depending on enemy weakenesses and resistances.

While I don't consider myu self that great at it, the combat is pretty simple but fun in this random weirdos opinion.
And then there's the Battle Sprites. These are virtual pets that offer extra attacks and abilities as they grow up like an omnipresent Pokemon. They don't break the game but they are useful with currently three types: damage, poison and healing. They don't get in the way and can actually be ignored if you want, which is fine by me but I like that the Battle Sprites give you boons to attacks or defence as they grow on top of boosting their own attacks.

Now, it sounds great right?

The issue is how Three Rings pays for all this...The Energy system demands money from you or you will go insane. Energy is an extra currency that works over the top of Crowns (Spiral Knight's money). Energy buys extra lives when you die, upgrades, various special weapons and more. Also, it's never really given to you for free. You either pay for it in Crowns, which is found within the game by simply playing, or with hard cash.

Other free to play games are happy for you to just chip in a few coins their way occationally if you feel like it.

Spiral Knights demands that you throw them cash in order to get the best equipment possible without grinding for half an eon to get enough Crowns. At lower levels of the game, this is harsh grinding if you don't have the cash to pay for Energy. To add to the issue, the levels are not that varied. They're not bad, they just repeat a lot. So, in order to get that cash, you have to run through the game over and over and over and over. If your gear isn't good enough, you'll die over and over, losing any heat (Experience, used for upgrading weapons) you've earned. You'll keep your Crowns but it's still no fun to be crushed into the dirt over and over just for some game essencials.

To add to this, the game demands that you have a certain level in all of your equipment before going forwards. Yes, this shows that the game's difficulty is about to spike upwards and you'll need the ugrade across the board but the issues with grinding come to slap you right across the face. If you don't grind though the same 10 or 20 levels, you cannot continue.

I cannot recomend this for casual or general players. It's enjoyable but I can imagine a lot of players just giving up at the first equipment check point. I would recomend giving it a go to see how else to make an MMO but I can't say that the Business Model for this game is the best compared to it's competitors. If your not afraid of some awful grinding, you can find some enjoyable gameplay here.

Oh! Three Rings? Make a Single Player game based on this! It would be awesome! I want to see more of this world.

reviewText: It was a game that was fun at first. For maybe 3 or 4 hours. Back when it started it was much simpler, though had a lot of pay to play in it. only doing 10 levels a day for free wasn't enough to accomplish anything substantial. But when you start you think it's all good and fun. But after you get to say 3 star gear, you start to notice the game has nothing else. You basically did everything that is in the game. After that its just rinse and repeats, and an endless grind fest of doing the exact same thing over and over again. The only thing different after that is the boss battles. And even those add an amount of new content to the game that only lasts about 5 seconds. Once you beat Vanaduke all thats left is collecting costumes and accessories and playing a dress up game. And as a final note, the Dev team is absolutely god awful. By far one of the all time worst support teams I have ever seen in my entire life. They basically arent even a support team, they're just there to make you think you will get support only to tell you days or even weeks later that what you did is something they wont help you with, and basically give you the finger and say live with the mistake you made.\n-A once former player, who saw the horror of how terribly flawed this game is far too late.

reviewText:
While this game got huge updates, it also got huge downgrades as well.
For example: the forge. Just the forge, the concept comes out as a refreshing new mechanic and it ends being the worst enemy. You will make more progress in the game before you get your 5 star weapon to lvl 10.
The servers are atrocious, not only they make the game certainly unplayable if you live far from the server's reach, but you will never be able to finish a level without dying for the server lag making you walk over spikes or enemies.
Sometimes you wish you should be playing this game with a group, and most people never play in groups.
Is a sad thing to say, but it's the truth.
Spiral Knights WAS a great game, but right now, they need to fix all the issues that handicaps the game and makes it a rather unpleasant experience.

reviewText:
I'll have to say, this game is extremely easy to adapt to when playing, but I found it to be extremely grindy unless you have real money, and then its a serious piece of cakewalk.

In recent updates, they have given more ways to stick you behind the passing line for things such as Tier 5 gear and even upgrading levels on your gear, by putting a new long and dreadful leveling system and forge (which are new features as of now from this game being out since June 14, 2011). Energy is mainly from purchasing with real money, which from that, energy is needed for crafting (and lots of it), and for leveling up gear (again, lots of it).

Nothing really big has been additioned to the game, its all the same constant going down floors upon floors of adventuring, with nothing more than that (besides the PvP which is more like minigames).

To be honest, im surprised it has so many people active on it, with all sorts of restrictions to those who dont have physical money to spend in this game, I have a spectacularly horrid time doing anything in the game now due to these new restrictions, since im forced to stay with the same leveled gear that I cannot actually level up without grinding for days, or spending real money.

Key words, folks: Real money.

reviewText:
Spiral Knights is a MMO that plays like Diablo on fast forward. But this hack-and-slash RPG action is tempered by a spiteful pricing system that seems determined to stop you playing just as you’re starting to have fun.
The story of this game is that members of the Spiral Knights stranded on an alien planet, it’s our mission to hunt for the materials needed to get the Order’s spacecraft up and running so we can return home. That means fighting through The Clockworks: a series of layered dungeons leading to the core of the planet.
The Clockworks are vast, and full of monsters that vary according to the theme of each level. Forest areas contain wolvers and other wild creatures, while electric zones will have more robotic foes. Of course levels can have combined family mosters and statuses. Each level is full of spike traps, turrets and danger rooms"
Each Knight can carry two weapons at a time (you can buy extra weapon slots at the NPC market in exchange for energy)
recommended: and switch between them at will. Controlling your knight couldn’t be easier. A quick click will swipe or fire your weapon
hoursPlayed: you can hold down the button for a charged attack or press X to trow up a shield who will protect you for any damage on any side
voteText: but the shield can break and it has to recharge and you have to wait some time. From the safe city of Haven
helpfulPercent: you can form a party of up to four knights
votesHelpful: dive into a clockworks and immediately start your hunt for items. Every reward feeds back into the complex levelling system.\nProgression in Spiral Knights is all about crafting. The level of your armour determines the depth you are allowed to reach. Higher tier weapons can be bought at massive prices
votesTotal: but it’s much more sensible to make them. If you don't have the materials you need you have to go the to NPC who trades tokens for materials.\nIn the past In Spiral Knights
votesFunny: everyday actions such as pressing a button on an elevator
commentsCount: crafting new items and reviving your knight all cost you energy but this has changed and now every player doesn't need to wait 24 hours for energy to regenerate or buy more of it.\nSpiral Knights is fast

reviewText:
Overall, I love this game.  I have been playing since March 2012, with more than 2k hours, but I did not start off on Steam, so you can't see that.

Graphics:
The graphics are amazing, that's all I really have to say.  They are very smooth and refined, unless you have low graphics or graphics glitches, which I don't.  Both on the knights and on the monsters, there is detail, but not so much to make them realistic, which I think would ruin the game.

Advancing:
It's an MMO, be prepared to grind.  I have completed the game (mostly) so I don't have to worry about grinding, but there is a massive grindwall.  For the most part, I got over this grindwall F2P, which is possible, but it is hard.  If you want to get over this grindwall, I suggest grinding with friends.  If you don't have any friends, go make some!  This game has an awesome community!  As long as you're not a beggar...

Weaponry:
I will be rather blunt here.  Some of the weaponry is extremely unrealistic, and some of it is waaay too OP.  The Dark Retribution (the DLC bomb) is rediculously powerful.  It can cause massive damage in a matter of seconds, redering everything else obsolete, depending on what you are fighting.

The rapiers in the game (flourishes and Snarby swords) are the only swords of their damage type, leaving you no other options, unfortunately.  Personally, I love them, but if you don't, you're out of luck.

The guns in the game are fairly well balanced, but, as with everything, some are better than others.  Recently, the Magnus/Tundrus line has become OP, but before they were useless.  Pulsar lines are not as powerful as before, but they are still a good choice of weaponry.  The Antigua lines are situational: you don't want to use them against just anything.

Lastly, some of the weaponry is just terrible for everything, even though they look powerful.

PvP:
P2W. P2W. P2W.  PvP is based on unique variants that you have to spend a lot of money to get.  You also have to have the right armor, some of which is hard to acquire.  The weapons are NOT balanced.  Rocket Hammers, rapiers, Pulsars, Sealed Sword lines, and Brandishes are all OP, but some other things that are great on monsters, such as the Blitz Needle, are terrible.

Community:
The community is very small, which is an advantage.  A lot of the players are older, mature people.  If anyone acts like a ♥♥♥♥, EVERYONE soon knows it, and they can be shunned.  The P2W Lockdown players (PvP) can be those ♥♥♥♥♥, but, knowing some of them myself, not all of them are that bad.  One problem with the general community is the noobs that don't know how to grind.  They sit there begging for money in Haven (the safe zone).  Personally, I hate it.

Guilds are an amazing part of the game, which boost the community.  Guilds are groups of players, and your guild is sort of like an entension of your friends list.  You can do guild versus guild Lockdown, which can be very enjoyable, unless you are a small guild person like me.  Unfortunately, the guilds with the richer players have more members.  Wealth attracts people.

Conclusion:
Although I have found many faults in this game, it is my favorite game.  This game has ruined my life.  If you are a player of MMOs, you would enjoy this game greatly.  I think I'll give this game a 9.5/10.
voteText: 8 of 13 people (62%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Spiral knights is a great game for those of you that like games that you can get bored of and come back to easily, but sometimes it punishes you, because with every update that spiral knights gets it becomes harder to progress, and there is a  wall that you will encounter eventually in progression to where you either need to grind your heart out, (hence getting bored of and later coming back to) or pay to skip it. reviewText:
This is going to be a short review.

Spiral knights is 3rd person MMO.
In it you go climb down one level at a time, clearing it.
While it does get really repedative (Which is my main problem with the game) the community is really friendly and the game is pretty challenging. (Which I consider to be a good thing but some people might disagree)

Lets cut to the chase, Spiral knights is a game for people who can grind for hours or just have the money to spend.
The game is just your normal P2W MMO.
Although you can get most items by grinding, it will most likely take you hours or days for a single item.
While the difficulty spike does rise drastically, SK keeps it fair and is pretty managable if you can play well.

While all the things above are true there is also a great deal of unique items and events each year.
The comunity is a very pleasant one, although it doesent exactly make up for the game's problems.

The game is appropriate for each audiance as it does moderate it's chat.
I honestly find myself sighting heavily each time I need to make a new item.
It takes so much time and effort to grind in this game.

I do not recommend it unless you find yourself having too much money and not knowing what to do with them.

reviewText:
I've played a lot of this game, way more than I would have liked to in retrospect.
And I sit here wonder only what could have been.

My initial attraction to the game was through its gameplay reminicent of top-down zelda games and its art style because, I admit, im a sucker for cute ♥♥♥♥. And while I frequently reminice of my days of old when the game was still fresh and new to me, I today am only disilusioned and disenfranchized to it all. I'll start by getting the good out of the way.

As I said the gameplay is reminicent of earlier zeldas. There are a variety of damage and armor types as well as different enemy factions with strengths and weaknesses in acordance to these types. The enemy types are nicely varied and require different tactics to them. There are swords, guns, and bombs to use and equip. The arcade is essentially a sandbox element where you trek through different randomized levels. And there is good fun to be had when you take your first steps into Cradle.

Then you hit it, the massive brick wall called end game". A herculian task of overcoming frustrating RNG and tedium to get the 2nd highest level armor
date: then tripled that for the highest quality. Now that might not sound so bad
recommended: I mean reallly good gear should be worked for right? Well the thing is that its required to progress through the game. It's not fancy gear you can choose to get
hoursPlayed: you must get a full set of certian quality gear in order to progress through the story as there are missions that quite literally only serve as a gear check. And then you see the energy bar in the bottom corner taunting you to spend some cash to make the pain stop.\n\nAfter smashing your head against said brick wall for hours on end
voteText: or simply paying to make the pain stop
helpfulPercent: you are introduced into an end game world of freakishly overpriced fashion items and RNG prize boxes. This is a game where the endgame is cosmetic items
votesHelpful: but due to the abhorent RNG and rarity of these items
votesTotal: they cost upwards of 20$-100$+ of real money. You can spend in game currency to buy premium currency (energy) which is whats often used for trading of these accessories
votesFunny: good luck getting anywhere if you dont plan to grind one single level and one single boss for all eternity. So unless you have enough money to smash your way into this impenetrable market
commentsCount: the accessory trade is strictly for veterans and no one else.\n\nBy the time you have the end game gear
column16: you have already done most of everything this game has to offer. That deceptive climb to the top was just padding. All but the shadow lairs which are the games only end game content that a regular player would probably enjoy. But those have an up front cost of 1800 (~20$) energy just to get a key to play one. And these lairs are just altered versions of already existing boss levels.\n\nThe plot of the game is "intrigue" and thats it. You crash land on a random planet made of clockwork and machinery. Your goal is to get to the center of the planet

reviewText: On the outside, Spiral Knights comes across as some kind of childs Diablo. It starts out fun but soon becomes sadistic. The developers seem to have attempted to create an A-RPG that sticks out from others. Upon doing so though, they left out some important qaulities, whilst also ruining the ones they kept. The game is very unrewarding and requires more grinding than even the most hardcore of MMO's. I suspect they thought by doing so, it would encourage more microtransactions. Clearly that's not the case judging by the low player base. The game had a lot of potential but ultimately becomes a repetative chore early on. 55/100

reviewText: I've been playing Spiral Knights now for months. While people say it's bad, I gave it a try instead of listening to Game Reviews. I listened to the people that played the game. Since then, I never looked back. This game is awesome. Sure, it might have Lag problems sometimes when there's a lot of people on, but what game doesn't have that? Also, it has a ton of things you can buy with your money as well as awesome DLC. Another good thing about this game is that you can farm Gold and turn it into Energy. Energy is the games In Game Currency you have to buy with Real Money. If you farm for the gold, you'll never have to spend a dime on the game. Plus they even made the DLC for the game buyable with Enegy as well. Not many games I know have this Setup this game does. I can't recomend it enough to people.

reviewText:
For the most part, the game is ok. You go through dungeons, level up your gear and rank up into harder areas, allowing for better gear. But it soon becomes apparent that there is a massive paywall to advance. Although it can be avoided, this leads to IMMEASUREABLE amounts of grinding the same either bosses or Arcade levels constantly to either get enough of the currency, find any orbs required to ccraft new gear to advance to the higher ranks and finding the ridiculous amount of crystals needed to level up your current gear 10 times so you can buy new gear... and the droprates of all of these things is so low you can go through 10s of hours without actually having found a single one.
Another turnoff is that unless you already have them, there are 5 now impossible to get achiements, meaning you can't begin this game and aim to get 100%.
The final downfall of this game though... is there is pretty much no endgame content at all, which hasn't changed for years, and very likely won't change any time soon, or possibly even at all, so once finished it may just seem really pointless trying to continue.
In all seriousness, this game... if you like this sort of genre and you are going in with some friends, or you are great at making online friends, this game can be a lot of fun regardless of the insane grinding as the community is actually very nice for the most part.
Although it has a  redeeming feature of its friendly casual atmosphere;  it can get insanely boring and painful to even bother,
...so I can't recommend this game.
Should you play Spiral Knights...? It's up to you... either try it out for yourself, or just leave it, If it doesn't look very good to you, you will not like it.

reviewText:
What can be said about Spiral Knights?

Well for starters it's a game by Three Rings and Sega, and is the first MMO Sega has ever produced.

Its Story:
You're a knight from a distant land on search for a grand power source to save said distant land, and as you and the the rest of the crew find the source, it retaliates, stranding you on the grand mechanical world of The Cradle.
Many realms and creatures await you in this complex world.

Graphics:
Standard graphics cards can play this game with no problem minus resolution lags and such.
8/10

Design:
Cute, sleek, & bright knight characters to build with, even in basic gear! Enemies are pretty cute too, Wolvers and Gremlins being personal favorites of mine.
9/10

Soundtrack:
Bubbly and very new age meets soft electronic, giving this game its signature sci-fi meets cute feel.
9/10

Replay rate:
Due to the fact that its an ever changing world, has a fun & complex crafting system, many cosmetic & weaponry options, expansive mission based modes & great a for farming arcade mode. Yeah...High Replay rate.
10/10

Need for cash (Pay to play?/Pay to win?):
Now I won't sit here and tell you that you don't HAVE to have money to play this game to it's fullest potential, but its always a cool thing to spend a little bit extra to have that one thing you've been NEEDING to finish a cool high powered set. And sometimes, an open wallet helps.
7/10

OVERALL!
9/10

You can play this damn game for free or not! It don't change the fun factor, just makes it longer!

reviewText:
A great F2P game, the game itself is great, with the storyline being where you can choose to pay attention to it, or just do the missions. The game itself is still in development with multiple updates having changed it from its original self, and I can only say that it's a good thing.

There are 3 ways to fight, bomb, gun, and sword. Each one of these has its own perks. Guns can pack devastating status effects, fire several shots at once, and take enemies out at a distance (though with the way rooms are designed, pure gunning can be hard, but satisfying).

Swords are just that, swords, they are the melee weapon of the game, some are your basic BFS (big fat sword), others are speed slicers, and others are status weapons for specific areas. The only downside to using a sword is that you have to usually be in the thick of the enemies to do the damage needed, and can put you at a disadvantage at times when needing to flip a switch, though the game itself provides jars to throw at the switches usually in case you pure-sword.

Bombs are my personal favorite, while pure bombers are rare, they can be devastating when they are fully upgraded. Bombs come in a few different types, combat controlling, status inflicting, damage dealing, and shard. Combat controlling usually are the gravity bombs, which pull all enemies into the same spot for a bit before exploding, great for rooms with large amounts of monsters. Status inflicting bombs don't do a lot of damage, but the effect they do can greatly ease a fight, especially the frost bomb that freezes ALL enemies in their tracks. Damage bombs are just that, they focus on pure damage, they usually have quite a bit of knockback and are great for packed rooms. Shard bombs are multiple explosion bombs that come in a few different types that I won't go super in depth for. The downside of the bomb is that while other weapons have a basic attack and a charge, bombs only charge, so bombs can take an incredibly long time to charge without any perks, and you are vulnerable while charging.

A great game overall, and its randomized floor system means you hardly ever do the same run twice.

reviewText:
By all means I shouldn't be recommending this game.

But here I am.

I guess things are best seen from the beginning.

I may bash Spiral Knights, but I love this game and have no idea what I'm going to say from here on.

Please understand, I have trouble starting this review.  I've played this game for 4 years now, I've never put this kind of committment into a game until Spiral Knights.  I was in 8th grade and found this gem when browsing Steam.  Let's start here.

My download speeds were horrid (and still are), every game I downloaded was a committment.  I was immediately graced with this bright, cheerful music.  The title page loaded in, and I signed in through Steam (can't forget my first login), and I began my trek.  I designed this cute little knight, or so I thought.  I gave him a nice dark blue color, and unknowingly selected the fancy color pallet, which sort of disgusts me now.  I had three options; Helment(3), Armor(3), and Color(not counting).  He was my little hero, and I fell in love with the aesthetics of the crash site.  I again was immursed with the soundtrack, and loved the bright and colorful environment.  It felt open, I was free.  Free to do what?  Hell if I knew, but this felt so good.

That was 2011.

I can't help but wonder what went so wrong with this little gem.  All I see now are costumes and reasons to invest realworld money in the game.  I want those days back.  That's our society, isn't it?  The constant wanting of our innocence, but nobody can grant these things.

I was around 400 hours in and it was 2012.  I miss these days, Crimsonhammer was just released.  People complained of how OP the new weapons were.  Me?  Oh, I couldn't have cared less of which weapon was the best, I had my jolly little brigade, and we would delve into T2 of the clockworks, using the last of our Mist Energy on a single revive, as the living would desperately sprint from body to body, awakening our corpses to fight again.

This is not to say I didn't care of Crimsonhammer, but I had my little brigade, and I was content.  The grind was beautiful, and I could play this game forever, fighting my favorite boss, Roarmulus.  I never understood why nobody seemed to like these two.  In my messed up head, they were so beautiful.  I couldn't help but grind them, not because I had built solid Elemental Damage, but because my Fireburst Brandish had an itching for cogs that I was too eager to fulfill.

I specifically remember a conversation at the end of the T2 clockworks with some knight who had been a tremendous joy to delve with.  We would go back and forth for what must have been half an hour, discussing our experiences and dissapointments with Spiral Knight's blatant abandonment of F2P players (Crimsonhammer) (I was still F2P).

I really don't want to continue, the more I type, the more I remember.  My point is that this game holds tremendous sentimental value, but nothing I can say will ever change its longevity.

That little brigade and I went our seperate ways.  I only have contact with one, and he and I have become more distant with each passing week; I guess it really hurts that I never said goodbye to any of them.  I just dissapeared and my young mind was attracted to newer and better? games.

This has been something looming over my head for around 2 years now, and I couldn't imagine a better time to look back and remember the past.  This is the season to be thankful.


You know, with  Black Friday    ...err Turkey Day on the horizon.

reviewText:
Free to Play!
Spiral Knights is free to play, no subscription is required to enjoy everything the game has to offer.

Spiral Knights is a cooperative adventure in a persistent world with a focus on instant, fast-paced action. Arm yourself and join the ranks of the Spiral Knights, stranded on an alien world, they must explore the ever-changing Clockworks beneath its surface in hopes of reaching its mysterious Core.
The Clockworks offer challenges that are best tackled with friends.

OpinionGradeFight monsters, solve puzzles and discover treasures together!(10/10)Everything looks very nice.(10/10)You can choose any type of controller you want, such as mouse, keyboard or joystick (10/10)
This game can be very good if you have friends and you're patient, but if not then it's not for ya... anyway this game doesn't cost a penny, so better try it.
Rate: 10/10

reviewText:
First off: This is honestly the best free-to-play game you will find on Steam.
The graphics are intuitive and maintain the perfect balance between realism and cartoonishness. The community is incredibly nice and supportive (hello, Dota 2?) and the possibilities to play with others are endless.

One of the best things about this game is that even if you replay a mission over and over again, the scenario and map you are put into is never the same. There's an infinite number of possible map layouts for every mission, and the missions always have something different that makes that certain mission special and unique.

Another major plus is that it requires no grinding/farming to achieve the highest level, and even once you have the best gear and have completed all of the regular missions, there's still so much you can do. There's room to have up to three games on one account so you can always start anew, and if you really think you've accomplished everything there is to accomplish on one game, you can always delete it and start again, opening up another new world of possibilities and game-changing decisions to experiment with.

Being a Youtuber (PeaceOfMined), the guild and party options are incredibly useful and fun to record on, especially with the voice-sync (although it is kind of slow). The armor and sword combinations are endless, and with the battle sprites and all the different skills and compositions in one party comes a feeling that you're playing the perfect blend of Spiral Knights and League of Legends, where you have all the abilities and attack possibilities of League, and along with it have the intuitive control system, open-world feeling, and extra attacking options of Spiral Knights, as well as the manual team composition and chatting system.

One last thing is the addictiveness of the game itself. I'm a full time student as well as a musician, Youtuber and athlete. What you may notice is I seem to have more hours on record than would seem possible with a schedule like that. I agree. Spiral Knights is a very addicting game. If you have a steady job, be prepared to leave Spiral Knights for a week, as you won't like it one bit.

Me: Mom can I take a short break from my homework
Mom: Sure you've been at it for three hours
Me: *opens Spiral Knights*
Mom: (seven hours later) Are you done your homework yet? It's past midnight
Me: Yeah just a second
Me: *the next morning* Hey mr. teacher I couldn't finish my homework last night
Teacher: Why
Me: I was training
Teacher: You were playing Spiral Knights
Me: How can you tell
Teacher: Im secretly your friend on steam and i was in your party for five hours straight
Me: subscribe to my channel
Teacher: Already done
Me: Jesus christ what have you been doing with your life
Teacher: Spiral Knights ;D

I challenge you to find a better PC open-world dungeon crawler, paid or not. Comment on my Spiral Knights YouTube videos if you find one I should review. (https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCXN5MB1UIN1aH2FRw-rPV9g)

Overall Rating (There's no infinity symbol on the keyboard):  infinity/10
