reviewText:
This game has in my mind one of the best artstyles out of any game on Steam
I adore it, just so gorgeous. That beautiful mix of low-poly models and crisp, contrasting colours that you only ever see when you emulate a DS game in HD or something. The environments, equipment, robots and creatures feel varied and incentivised my exploration with the intent of finding yet more for my eyes to gorge on. I can't stress enough how filled with charm the visuals are.
I love the inflection to the sound design too, but that's a weird thing to say. The majestic music and the way sound effects sound when navigating the UI / attacking / picking up items or whatever. It is just, satisfying and comfy??
The art and sound team did such a stellar job, I hope they're doing big things somewhere nowadays.
Give her a listen https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8exyC9_EnP4

Now, the game itself? It hasn't been updated with any real content in a long, long time. The cash store has the game by a chokehold and there is almost no way to play the game without spending money to alleviate crazy grind. The servers are becoming barren and the game is becoming less and less well optimised as time goes on. (Not to mention some really naff gameplay changes here and there for the worse)

It isn't necessarily that the gameplay is bad, it's just that the game is absolutely dead. And that is a bitter pill to swallow. There's nothing worse in my mind than wasted potential, and this game had its A-game set up for everything besides longevity.

This is a free to play MMO first and foremost, focussed on teamwork and equipment progression. By that nature, you'll need to grab some friends to help you power through the content, because you're not getting through it on your own or cheaply.

Cute robots are my weakness and for that reason I'm giving the game a 10/10

reviewText:
20/05/2012 C.E.

This is a game for all people. Its main aim is teamwork, as you can do anything alone in this game, but it would take MUCH longer. For example, doing a level by yourself would take 30minutes, but with others helping, it would take 10 minutes instead. I really recommend this game, except for the part where elevators charge you to use them.

20/07/2014 C.E.

This game now sucks. Ever since the main developer (Nick) left, the events have all been recycled constantly. With no new ideas, the game is stagnating faster than ever before. The only new updates are purely cosmetic modifications. (Quite less recently, a new system was introduced to make heating gear a little more complicated, but it was still mostly straightforward, until 5* crystals were made impossible to farm, forcing players to rely on energy more and more.)

Also, OOO refuses to port to Steam for Linux, cutting off many of its own players. The game's suckiness has reached an all-time low.

reviewText:
Don't be fooled. This game might have a cute and coloful look but what makes it a true gem is that it requires skill to master and plenty to keep the challange going while the COOP aspect adds infinite replayability.

This is a true action game with one of the best combat systems I've come across. It feels balanced with enough variety to keep it interesting and engaging, but with enough simplicity to keep it from being unnecessarly bloated like many other games with weapon/armor upgrades end up feeling. Every enemy is fought differently and certain weapons work best against them. With all the different specialization routes like buffing up on armor, gunning, bombing, slow swords, fast swords, knockback techniques, precise shielding and dozens of different enemies on screen, it is truly rewarding to master.

Although this game can be played exclusivly solo, the thing that really makes this game never-ending is the COOP. Technically it is a MMO but parties are limited to 4 players that must work together with different strategies to complete levels.

Like any other game, it does have shortcomings, most notably the steep learning curve pertaning to making and using the variety of gear that is available, However, if you enjoy challanging action games with plenty of upgrading and COOP, you should absolutely must give this a try.

reviewText: This is a great game for anyone who's never played it before. It's casual so everyone can enjoy it, but offers a sense of progression. It's an absolute blast if you have friends to play with. If you like the idea of a 4-player Legend of Zelda, give this game a shot. It's truly free-to-play now, and you don't need to spend money to progress. PvP can be insanely fun but does require a big time investment. reviewText:
I won't write a super long and informative review, so let's boil it down.

Spiral Knights turned a new leaf a year or two ago and it wasn't so much a moneysink, as of now you don't have mist energy, lifts are free, and crafting costs aren't ♥♥♥♥ing insane like they used to be. Everything is cute, so in contrast to other hack-n-slash games this is great if you're a squeamish person. I, personally am not and I prefer to have my enemies twitching with blood gushing out is a reward by itself. Combat is a bit slow, but incredibly fun, especially with a party because the game attempts to swarm you with enemies, and it's cool to personally smack each and every one of them with your sword, bomb or gun.

The thing that got on my nerves the most in this game are overspecialization of weapons. Each enemy does different types of damage, Elemental, Piercing, and shadow, and you can find yourself screwed if you show up to a level full of shadow damage dealing enemies with elemental Armour, and you're much more vulnerable. The weapon damage system is similar, enemies can either be very good at resisting a damage type or very weak to it; making weapons tremendously more situational and will cause you to grind more just so you can be the jack of all trades. The game as it is now has basically turned into Team Fortess 2 in the dress-up aspect except the game's content and enjoyment comes to a stop in a certain point because the development team doesn't feel like making actual new content and resorts to making Spiral Knights endgame a big dress up.

A good multiplayer hack-n-slash that's being held back by major flaws.

reviewText:
It's a 4 Player F2P CO:OP Dungeon Crawler Game (You can also play with less than 4 players or search for a random group ingame) where you need to get through missions and find out why you crashed and if you can get back to your homeworld again.

The game is extreme fun at the beginning but can be pretty frustrating, at least if you face the fact that you need to mostly grind stuff and money in the late game (It's possible to buy it with real money tho).

With friends even that can be very much fun tho!

I'd recommend this game for everyone who likes dungeon-crawler games, but I'd only give it 7/10.

reviewText:
Don't be fooled. This game might have a cute and coloful look but what makes it a true gem is that it requires skill to master and plenty to keep the challange going while the COOP aspect adds infinite replayability.

This is a true action game with one of the best combat systems I've come across. It feels balanced with enough variety to keep it interesting and engaging, but with enough simplicity to keep it from being unnecessarly bloated like many other games with weapon/armor upgrades end up feeling. Every enemy is fought differently and certain weapons work best against them. With all the different specialization routes like buffing up on armor, gunning, bombing, slow swords, fast swords, knockback techniques, precise shielding and dozens of different enemies on screen, it is truly rewarding to master.

Although this game can be played exclusivly solo, the thing that really makes this game never-ending is the COOP. Technically it is a MMO but parties are limited to 4 players that must work together with different strategies to complete levels.

Like any other game, it does have shortcomings, most notably the steep learning curve pertaning to making and using the variety of gear that is available, However, if you enjoy challanging action games with plenty of upgrading and COOP, you should absolutely must give this a try.

reviewText:
Awesome game!

Music is great, storyline is interesting, graphics are excellent, deep game. Lots of gear, different surroundings, such as haunted mansions, graveyards, metallic cities, forests, etc.

Something's I've noticed however is, the further you go into the Clockworks, the harder the AI becomes, so its important you get a friend or friends to help you.

There is one thing that is confusing about this game. And that is buying new gear. There is like nothing to buy in the markets until you reach a certain rank. Then, your granted access to the Hall of Hero's, where you can buy recipes to craft new, better, stronger gear. But that seems to be it, as far as getting new gear goes.

Overall, excellent game. 10/10

reviewText:
As a free to play it's a really good game. It was even updated recently to be more playable for everyone, getting out of the game some problems that ruined most of the gameplay and more additions to what was already good. Graphics are neat, community is nice and events are often present over the seasons.
Then why i am not recommending it?

Still some issues and bugs that seems to be hard to fix are present and ruin much of the gameplay, like often very bad sync with game server-computer, the need for a good and stable internet connection to play properly, even if you want to play alone.
Some little graphical glitches were fixed, other are still in game, but this don't really ruin the game; rather, sometimes these glitches could steal a smile.
And if you can bear these problems, there is still one big trouble.

Pay money = you advance better in the game = you win.

Some unique materials that are needed to create better weapons and gears can't be traded in any way, means you can't even buy/sell/give some of these pretty scarce materials to other players or friends. Instead, you can buy these from the shop in-game with a second currency, different than the standard one you can obtain playing the game, that requires you to pay a very big amount of the standard currency to buy this one, or you can easily get it by paying real money and getting bunches of this.

Even some little kind of upgrades that randomly appears while crafting your equipment are more expensive even than the cost of the strongest weapon themselves. This considering the mostly-real money currency.

Also some unbalance between the weapons is present, since some that have the same level than others that are less popular, are infact fairly better than these: even if there is an attack type system, some weapons that haven't the standard attack type are good just for EVERY kind of monster. And let's not speak when there is the weak type of monster against these weapons.

Overall the game is pretty nice, but even with my amount of hours spent i can't just recommend this game to everyone, mostly for the annoying sync system and the pay-to-win system, even if it's one of the lowest i ever seen in free to play games.

Gameplay at it's core

The core aspect of any game. The gameplay type involved is a dungeon crawler

reviewText:
I thought this game would be fun for my husband and I to play together.  Turns out, to play together you must be guild-mates.  To create a guild, you have to have crowns and energy.  The ONLY way to get energy?  Buy it with real money.

Energy will also buy you items to make your in-game weapons and armor better.  I hate pay to win games!

{ I added this next paragraph a month or so later.}

The Spiral Knights developers told us it may have been a glitch that day but we haven't tried again because we're playing the hell out of AirMech and Alien Swarm.  Thank you to the players that commented on my review without calling me names.

reviewText:
Great Free-2-Play hack-n-slash dungeon crawler  if you like cartoon graphics. Characters strength is fully dependant on items that you build and level, with a good range of options to fit different play styles.

Pros:
-Extremely fun for a F2P game
-New energy system removes the need to use the cash shop to compete
-Character progress completely dependant on progressing your weapons/armor by leveling them up
-Crafting system is extremely easy to use, yet provides the nessessary depth for a game dependant on crafting
-Difficulty scale allows you to choose how tough you want missions to be, with harder difficulty giving more loot!

Cons:
-Extremely easy missions at the start of the game that may give new plays a boring first impressions
-Immense time spent farming the same end game missions to build new items
-Lack of end game content other than PvP

Despite the cons, I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a cartoon style hack-n-slash dungeon crawler. It is incredibly fun for its niche and fun for players of all ages.

reviewText:
This game started very good and ended up getting bad as i progressed in the game. I have good experiences but also a few bad ones which eventually made me quit spiral knights.

I started playing together with a friend just to try it out but as we progressed i eventually came to the conclusion that it was a fun game so i got into it. During my plays i kept hitting several walls though. My first problem was the repetitive level design which started to look the same the more i played it. I dismissed that problem eventually in favor of the story line but my biggest problem was levelling the armor and weapons, the higher tier i get the harder it becomes to get the crafting materials thus more tempting it gets to purchase what items you need from the store with real money. You can't progress the storyline unless you level up your armor at least 5 times at set points in the story line.

This means you either have to grind insane amounts of levels and trade a lot of it with others in order to get the amounts of ingame currency or do it the easy attractive way and convert real currency such as dollars pounds or euros at the ingame store to energy used to buy weapons and armor at prices which eventually equals the price of a full new retail price of a game if not more. The transaction options didn't sit very well with me either, You can either pay by credit card which is pretty normal here on steam for people aged 18 and over but here's the thing. You can pay by text message as well. Just give the ingame store your cellphone number and they send you a message, You agree and they make money from the message you send. What do all the kids walk around with these days? They all have cellphones that the parents gave them and that text message transaction option will make it very tempting for underage kids to make the mistake by going overboard with their cellhpone without the parent's consult.

I'm not too fond of this kind of practises. I had much fun with this game and that won't be forgotten but the more i played the more downhill it went. I abandoned it when i reached the 4 star armor cap and i'm fine with it. The only thing i will miss is the helpful community that this game has. It saved my bacon more than once.

Still, don't let all this discourage you from trying it out. This game is free to play and you can download this game for yourself whenever you like and form an opinion based on your own experiences. That is something i can recommend.

I hope my info has been helpful to you.


All the best!

(s.i.e)

reviewText:
This is your basic Pay to Win crap.  I couldn't even play a mission with my wife because I didn't want to spend money on anything yet.  Which means yes, if you're planning on downloading this to play with a friend, you need to spend real money to be able to do so.  Or you could grind for 7,800 'crowns' just to trade for 100 'energy'.  Energy is the bane of this game's existence.  If you haven't figured out yet, energy is what you buy with real life money.

The game mechanics themselves are fun, but the Pay 2 Win (in this case, pay to even play with a friend) aspect really killed the game for me.

Grade: D

This game had much potential, but the P2W aspect ruins it.  Not to mention the trolls and spammers.  One person was walking around just begging my friend and I to trade and spamming requests...I traded once with him, my friend didn't...but this guy didn't relent.  He just kept on trollin': running around us, spamming chat and trade requests.  This and one other person were in the Arcade.  I don't kknow about you, but I don't like games with $h!tty communities!

reviewText: Spiral Knights is a highly unique action based MMORPG unlike any other. It draws heavily from the top down Zeldas but throws a lot of other things into the mix, such as Bomberman. With a good progression system, lots of unique weapons, interesting pets, and simple systems, it's a plain great game. Sadly, there's little balance to be found in the game and the developers aren't quite in touch with the community. The community is pretty friggin' great, however. The devs wouild gain a lot from listening a bit more to it.\n\nThe game used to be much more pay to play but since half a year ago (summer 2013), it's truly free to play. The great majority of pay to play content comes in the form of promotions that cost Energy. Energy can be bought for real life money or the in game currency, crowns". Thus
date: there's no real life money barrier between any player and pay to play content
recommended:
which mostly consists of purely cosmetic items directed to end game players.

Another thing I truly like about this game is the art style. The characters are space marine knights with colourful armours and really cool weapons. There's also no sex-appeal involved. Characters don't even have anything that tells you whether they are men or women and that is probably one of the things that contribute to a community with so very little sexism.

Spiral Knights is truly a beautiful piece of art so stop reading this review and go play it."

reviewText:
Oh how far we've fallen... I've been playing this since 2010 and while there have been massive improvements, there have been massive failures.  Every update ends up requiring multiple shutdowns and restarts, latency has gone from annoying to game runing in several places, and once you've done everything once there really isn't anything more.

There have been no new levels, monsters, bosses, or anything for almost 2 years.  When this was new it was absolutely amazing and for new players it will be very fun.  But for those who have been around for a while it just doesn't do it anymore.

New weapons are great but if you're shooting at the same monsters over and over again in the same levels, it gets pretty boring after a while.  To be sure, you'll get hundreds of hours out of it, especially if you minimally pay and do it through old fashioned work.  But don't expect to stick around for years at near the same level of excitement.
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've been playing this game, on and off, long before it was released on Steam, since beta.  I played opening release weekend, late March 2011.  One of my characters has over 85 1/2 days of play time on it, thats 2000+ hours.

Great casual game:
+s, cute graphics, good music, great if you liked the Legend of Zelda games from NES, SNES, very simple combat style relative to most games.
-s, little content; especially end-game, no raiding (more than 4 player, player versus AI content), limited pvp options.  Story is weak.

If you're a casual player that can only log on for less than an hour to two hours a day to play, you'll find lots to do in this game without it feeling too grindy.  If you have more time to play than that per day, you'll get bored of this game relatively fast.

reviewText:
Long ago. 3 years ago, on Aug 27, 2011. I was but a young lad. young, naive, perhaps innocent. In the new world of Spiral Knights.

Spiraling down a chasm of confusion and curiosity, I was finally brought up with a recommendation to Spiral Knights. Filled with swords, pistols, shields, parties, dungeons, and list of items

The game Spiral knights(SK) from recollection memories during my first journey through it's dungeons and game-play nearly three years ago. Was enjoyable to say the least.


If you for one second can imagine an down graphics to appeal to the ages of 7-13 then probably this game is for you. If your into friendship and co-op through dungeons facing monsters with your trusty pistol or sword and shield, then perhaps this game is for you.

However, I digress. S.K. proved to be something that is beyond the average you normally see. Imagine yourself a kid, after the game boy era, the ps1 era, the xbox era, and you have an era of ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes. Granted, mmo's have existed since probably before the age of 2001 with WoW at its center.

The mmo S.K. is to be honest short lived game, pulling your slightest attention for the smallest of seconds through promotions with Team Fortress 2. Such was the case for me when I ashamedly downloaded this game for another TF2 hat promo from S.K.

Enjoyable in the sense, that I alone played by myself seeking for riches and glory. I didn't expect much, and that is proven by my hours spent on this game. Later on, I played with my friends together in a typical fashion of dungeon crawling and killing bosses. I'd compare SK to Torchlight, however both games are entirely different and this review isn't about a comparison.

It's about telling you my experience. As long as you have friends that back you up in this free to play game. You can literally have a good time. There is a grinding system, but only if you devote many of your efforts to getting the best equipment or the best item for you as soon as possible.

Though, in my case. I tried to go for higher quality items, but found it too troublesome to do so. Instead I focused on having fun delving into dungeons with friends in co-op. Laughing so hard when we die because of a stupid mistake like getting stuck in a trap. Or perhaps giving cheers for everyone when we all completed an item set or finished a boss.

If you like playing short-to-play games for free, and having fun with friends I would definetly reccomend this game for you.

After-all it's not often a studio would go so far to diversify itself for Triple A-A-A games in a Free-2-Play manner. Or would they?


(Original Post, Aug 27, 2011) Old score 7.29/10
(Re-edited Post Feb. 6, 2014) New score 7.3/10
(Score is based off how much I enjoyed playing the game)

reviewText:
I decided to review this game because I played extensivly and I have a feeling I can write a review based on my knowledge. Anyways this is my first review so if I make some sort of mistake let it slide.

So this game is Spiral Knights, a MMORPG that has a kinda in depth story, the story goes as follows apparently you are in a ship it's attacked, its about to blow up and you and all of your shipmates land on the Clockworks where monsters and creatures live in some hostile but some friendly. Spiral Knights also has a rank system which grants you the ability to make and weild/use better equipment. They are 10 ranks each with their own quests. But a big turn-down though is that sometimes there is a Hall of Heroes quest which requires you to have _ * Equipment...All of it. This leads to grinding for materials and Orbs of Alchemy, different types. Sometimes you can get stuck in this game because of this so the only choice you got is to save up those orbs. you are gonna need at least 15 orbs of whatever type to make the armor alongside other materials. However you eventually get this creature called a Battle Sprite which can help you fight but it wont attack by itself with default attacks, in fact it doesn't have a default attack which means you are responsible for any losses you have which can be a pain if you suck. Luckily it is pretty fun in general. Leveling up your Battle Sprite so it's stronger, getting new armor, weapons and sheilds, doing a quest for the first time, finding rare items. But it all boils down to do you like MMORPG's in general.

My ending note is this, Spiral Knights can be fun (and in some casses addicting) but it is much more fun with friends and when you are part of a guild. Either way making Armor and weapons aren't that fun and grinding can really be annoying but the amount of fun I have in each quest backs it up, if anything I think the best part for me is my Battle Sprite... Since this doesn't really have a rating system (Kinda but not really) I would give it a rating of 7/10. Its fun if you like RPGs and Doing quests and MMOs so. If you like these things I reccomend it, it is free so go for it if you wanna.

reviewText: Personally, I can't say much of this game. I quit the game almost early, because there was a broad storyline I could almost not follow, and the layout of the screen almost confused me at times. The graphics are still amazing for the game, but for myself ( who doesn't like when my UI is cramped) the game got boring quick. It quickly reminded me of my first days of WoW, and how I quit after a week of trying to get used to the cramped screen. Would not reccomend for anyone who is not used to the RPG feel of a cramped screen, but if you like a cramped screen, but would enjoy a more smooth and sci-fi graphical scene, this game is for you.

reviewText:
Never, EVER go near this game. IT has caused me an unbeleavable ammount of pain. STAY AWAY!!!!

It is very much pay2win oriented, since resurrecting in the dungeons uses up energy and you only get roughly 100 per day (and each time you revive, it's cost doubles, so first it's 10, then 20 then 40, etc.).
It is absolutely imperative that you live a maximum of 7 feet away from their servers, otherwise you'll have to predict enemy movement before they even telegraph it. Same goes for your own actions as you'll see your own sword pass through enemies unless you time it juuuuust right.
If you DO decide to play this, remember: your shield is TOOL to be used often. Use it's pushing ability to scatter surrounding enemies away before they strike (again, have to time it right or you'll get hit despite having your shield up).

Not recommended.

reviewText:
Play this game.

It's a dungeon crawler MMORPG with a dash of zelda inserted for good measure. The old 'free' mist energy may have been scrapped, but so have energy costs for elevators and alchemy. In short, buying energy with real money is now a shortcut, not a necessity. It's perfectly possible to play through the entire main game (i.e. the 'rank' missions) completely free.

There are no 'character levels', but your equipment gains 'heat' (basically exp), and after a certain amount is collected, you can level it up via the forge. Weapons 'evolve' through alchemy, and new weapons can be crafted via alchemy.

The main game has you play as a knight who completes various missions which revolve around exploring what is known as the clockworks and fighting various monsters there. Rank missions involve you exploring 2-3 levels of the clockworks each time, whereas using the arcade lets you explore more freely - once you've done enough rank missions, you can go from 'depth 0' to 'depth 29' in a single run.

The levels within the clockworks get progressively harder as you go deeper, and there are four main bosses to kill (as many times as you want) - and that's not including the difficult 'shadow lairs'. I feel that there's an emphasis on teamwork throughout the game (working as a team to complete missions makes it easier and you still get the same drops) and somewhat on player skill later on (even with excellent equipment, you'll still die if you're bad with a shield).

It should be said, however, that if you don't wish to fork out any cash for energy, then you may find that the grinding required to advance throughout the game may prove too repetitive and boring - experienced MMO players probably won't suffer from this issue, however.

Overall, I'd say this is a great game for those who enjoy MMOs, exploration and adventure. Me gusta.

reviewText:
In regards to Spiral Knights, I feel a heavy bit of nostalgia for Phantasy Star Online for the Dreamcast from this; be it the music, art style, or overall Sega feel. It's a candy coated, charming, and light action-rpg that I get an itch for when I'm away from it for a few months.

However It's a grind for gear, and there's not much in the way of customization or variety unless you play everyday in copy-cat grind-y dungeons, or shell out real money. Which, I believe, the game deserves.  The paywall feels like it hits as soon I as get in a groove, and snaps like a rubber band. I eventually come back, though, for the tight gameplay and charming design.

So yah, play it.

reviewText:
While the game is old, with updates over the past year the game has become much more free-to-play friendly than it use to be.

Elevators are now free and there is no longer a Mist bar, meaning endless dungeon crawling for everyone.

Leveling weapons is different, now requiring a specific item depending on the * of weapon. While hard to find at times, it is still possible to find the required item in Prize Boxes in through the dungeon.

The newer updates the game have put the focus back on exploration and spending time in the Clockworks and learning the game at your own pace, not buying everything with real world money and just spending time in pvp.

I have sunk easily 1000+ hours over the course of my time playing Spiral Knights and it will always be one of my most favorite games ever because of all of the memories I have made through the 3 years I have been playing.

reviewText: This is the best free to play MMORPG I've ever played.  I play this game direct from the website itself (www.spiralknights.com/play), that's why it looks like I haven't played much.  This game incorporates a number of themes smoothly into a fun adventure for gamers of all types.  This is a cooperative game that allows you to make friends and help them out, has a puzzle aspect in the levels, and the arcade portion of the clockworks is a genuine different adventure every day.  As new updates come out the game gets even better.  Updates aren't too far spaced and the new content is usually great.\nIn conclusion:  This is a great game that is really free to play if one puts in the effort.  Don't take for granted the cartoony/cute graphics, this is a genuine challenge that is worthy of even advanced gamers.  Try it.  See if you like it.  From an achievement you even get a nice TF2 hat.\n

reviewText:
Ah, Spiral Knights. How can I keep this recommendation within the character limit. Well, it's a free-to-play action-based MMO, but it remains free-to-play due to a mechanic that allows only so much playtime each day. And if you get addicted, which you will, you need to at least buy a monthly pass, that's basically required to enjoy the game anyway, unless you only have an hour or two to play each day anyway, in which case this is a perfect system for you. The game starts out easy, the controls are very simple, and they recently added an optional tutorial/questing system, which makes it even easier to start playing. However, things get insanely challenging later on. Bullet hells, spike hells, fiery helly hells. There are even special areas made just to be cruel hells. Admittedly it gets easier once you become experienced and know what to expect, but there are still areas that are basically impossible to progress through solo. This game will teach you how to use a shield, I'll say that.

UPDATE:

I'm changing this recommendation from positive to negative. This game is dying. A year ago, this was an underappreciated gem of an MMO. There was new content being regularly released for free that drew you in, and then while you were here there were cosmetics and boosts that you could pay for if you wanted to. This is how the free-to-play model should work, content that draws you in and keeps you playing while simultaneously not being locked behind a paywall and being open to anyone, whether they pay or not. And for the most part, this model still applies to new players who haven't experienced all the content yet.

But the new content updates that comprise the backbone of this model have long since died off. Promises were made and never kept, the lead developer upped and left, and a noticeably large chunk of the playerbase has died off due to boredom. It feels like a lot of drive and inspiration has been lost and Three Rings thinks it can fill this void with shiny new" reskins and repeating event content and hope that no one notices while they try to piece everything back together behind the scenes
date: IF they're trying to piece everything back together behind the scenes
recommended: maybe they aren't. It's been over a year now and there are STILL a bunch of unfixed problems and bugs related to the sprites update that was released just before everything fell apart.\n\nExamples: Some minerals have no purpose and get stuck in your inventory; sprites have a level numbering system that makes no sense
hoursPlayed: the "true" max level is some number over 100 that the game doesn't tell you; the only way of knowing that you've reached this "true" max level is that your sprite glitches out and stops accepting levelup food; and there are quite a few balance issues with pet abilties and ultimates

reviewText:
Background ethos: I have a playtime of 55:07:28:52, linked is an alt account. I've been a customer of OOO since 2007. I 'jumped ship' from Y!PP to this game in 2012.

This game is a hard sell. It is fun, vibrant and is both simple enough to pick up, and compelling enough to not put down. 2 years ago, I would say that once you get over the mist system, it's an excellent game I hope to see grow to be even better.
2 years later, I cannot reccommend this game wholeheartily due to the missteps it has taken. There is no getting past the top-heavy 'first act' of the game, restricting leveling system, redundancy-by-proxy mission system, and lack of an endgame.
These decisions and the overall lack of content to explore being added in any fashion sour the game experience for me. While the game remains something I come back to, I can no longer tell my friends to try it out, and I won't tell you, reader, either.

reviewText: When I started this game, I was young and innocent. I just wanted to buy Rome-Total War(tm), to enjoy the salutations of the people. How naive I was. Spiral Knights is an eldritch land, tugging at the edges of your soul until it gets hold of a jagged piece and rends you to the core, leaving naught but a torn, gangrenous wound in its wake. Any foolhardy traveller with the intention of tasting the Elysian nectar they believe this game to be, beware. For this is no nectar, but a venus flytrap, waiting, readying its gaping, ravenous maw to snap down upon your head. Stare long into the abyss, and the abyss will stare back into you, into your soul until it is nothing but its smoldering core. With these, my dying curses, I entreat ye, do not trust this abomination. They, the fallen, all said Its just to get another game"

reviewText:
Hey fellow reader who is reading this review, I shall not bombard you with lots of information and such, but just simply shorty and quickly tell you about this game.
This game is fun if you are out there to grind for maybe 2 hours a day for maybe 2 months to be able to get your wished armor, which at the end might not be the recommended for the game, but who ******* cares.
I used to play this game to get the best armour and the best weapons and stuff, but as it has been going on and on, well... Let's just say that the game has passed from getting your so wished armour into trying to look cool because yes, now you don't grind for the 5* armour, you will grind for the ideal costume, believe me, It has become into that.
Now looking into the Pay to win aspect, which is not totally wrong, you may pay and instantly skip to get that 5*armour and...
you know what I went and just said so much usless information, For the real point, if you hav someone to play with it is quite atractive and fun, but otherwise playing alone, nope that time has been long gone, solo playing was good before. Now I'd solely recomend to play with friends, beside a good part of the community are good persons. If you do decide to play solo simply find a good guild and I believe you might enjoy the game.
On the other hand there are some unobtainable achievments in the game, they should fix that cause those were old achievments from when the game had those capabilities.

reviewText:
This game is probably my second favorite game of all time. The gameply is in stages cartoony fun monsters while you play a cartoony fun character.

The game does get a bit grindy with 'orbs' if you dont want to pay money to get past having to try and get a bunch of rare rare orb drops so that you can get the higher teir armor. But in my opinion, the grinding is the best part because it makes you get better at the game.

The bosses are definetly challenging for the tiers. (except for the first one)

This game has very great gameplay up until you beat the game/get everything you want in the game. They havent really made anything to do afterwards, just a dress up RPG and look cool and maybe manage a guild

Over all I give this game a ★★★★☆, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText:
Play this game.

It's a dungeon crawler MMORPG with a dash of zelda inserted for good measure. The old 'free' mist energy may have been scrapped, but so have energy costs for elevators and alchemy. In short, buying energy with real money is now a shortcut, not a necessity. It's perfectly possible to play through the entire main game (i.e. the 'rank' missions) completely free.

There are no 'character levels', but your equipment gains 'heat' (basically exp), and after a certain amount is collected, you can level it up via the forge. Weapons 'evolve' through alchemy, and new weapons can be crafted via alchemy.

The main game has you play as a knight who completes various missions which revolve around exploring what is known as the clockworks and fighting various monsters there. Rank missions involve you exploring 2-3 levels of the clockworks each time, whereas using the arcade lets you explore more freely - once you've done enough rank missions, you can go from 'depth 0' to 'depth 29' in a single run.

The levels within the clockworks get progressively harder as you go deeper, and there are four main bosses to kill (as many times as you want) - and that's not including the difficult 'shadow lairs'. I feel that there's an emphasis on teamwork throughout the game (working as a team to complete missions makes it easier and you still get the same drops) and somewhat on player skill later on (even with excellent equipment, you'll still die if you're bad with a shield).

It should be said, however, that if you don't wish to fork out any cash for energy, then you may find that the grinding required to advance throughout the game may prove too repetitive and boring - experienced MMO players probably won't suffer from this issue, however.

Overall, I'd say this is a great game for those who enjoy MMOs, exploration and adventure. Me gusta.

reviewText: I do not play MMORPGs, so it's special when I say I play Spiral Knights. It's kept extremely simple, which makes it a great casual game that I can pick up and drop off without intense involvement. This is a good pizza-and-mouse game, meaning you can play one-handed due to the simplicity of the controls. It's a nice, calm, relaxing game, with stretches of tension and frustration. It's FtP, so there's limits on how much you can do in a 24 hour span, which kind of helps keeps me from seeing the limitations of the campaign missions. The skirmish missions are always different, but to clear a campaign, you must fight the same enemies on the same map. It has a difficulty spike in some areas. I love the visual design, and the music is an awesome combination of eight-bit and chill. Some of the collecting and trading aspects are difficult, as it isn't always easy to find someone who will buy what you want, even though it is extremely easy to buy items from others at the sub-ten tiers.  8.5/10.

reviewText:
I decided to review this game because I played extensivly and I have a feeling I can write a review based on my knowledge. Anyways this is my first review so if I make some sort of mistake let it slide.

So this game is Spiral Knights, a MMORPG that has a kinda in depth story, the story goes as follows apparently you are in a ship it's attacked, its about to blow up and you and all of your shipmates land on the Clockworks where monsters and creatures live in some hostile but some friendly. Spiral Knights also has a rank system which grants you the ability to make and weild/use better equipment. They are 10 ranks each with their own quests. But a big turn-down though is that sometimes there is a Hall of Heroes quest which requires you to have _ * Equipment...All of it. This leads to grinding for materials and Orbs of Alchemy, different types. Sometimes you can get stuck in this game because of this so the only choice you got is to save up those orbs. you are gonna need at least 15 orbs of whatever type to make the armor alongside other materials. However you eventually get this creature called a Battle Sprite which can help you fight but it wont attack by itself with default attacks, in fact it doesn't have a default attack which means you are responsible for any losses you have which can be a pain if you suck. Luckily it is pretty fun in general. Leveling up your Battle Sprite so it's stronger, getting new armor, weapons and sheilds, doing a quest for the first time, finding rare items. But it all boils down to do you like MMORPG's in general.

My ending note is this, Spiral Knights can be fun (and in some casses addicting) but it is much more fun with friends and when you are part of a guild. Either way making Armor and weapons aren't that fun and grinding can really be annoying but the amount of fun I have in each quest backs it up, if anything I think the best part for me is my Battle Sprite... Since this doesn't really have a rating system (Kinda but not really) I would give it a rating of 7/10. Its fun if you like RPGs and Doing quests and MMOs so. If you like these things I reccomend it, it is free so go for it if you wanna.

reviewText:
Ah, Spiral Knights. How can I keep this recommendation within the character limit. Well, it's a free-to-play action-based MMO, but it remains free-to-play due to a mechanic that allows only so much playtime each day. And if you get addicted, which you will, you need to at least buy a monthly pass, that's basically required to enjoy the game anyway, unless you only have an hour or two to play each day anyway, in which case this is a perfect system for you. The game starts out easy, the controls are very simple, and they recently added an optional tutorial/questing system, which makes it even easier to start playing. However, things get insanely challenging later on. Bullet hells, spike hells, fiery helly hells. There are even special areas made just to be cruel hells. Admittedly it gets easier once you become experienced and know what to expect, but there are still areas that are basically impossible to progress through solo. This game will teach you how to use a shield, I'll say that.

UPDATE:

I'm changing this recommendation from positive to negative. This game is dying. A year ago, this was an underappreciated gem of an MMO. There was new content being regularly released for free that drew you in, and then while you were here there were cosmetics and boosts that you could pay for if you wanted to. This is how the free-to-play model should work, content that draws you in and keeps you playing while simultaneously not being locked behind a paywall and being open to anyone, whether they pay or not. And for the most part, this model still applies to new players who haven't experienced all the content yet.

But the new content updates that comprise the backbone of this model have long since died off. Promises were made and never kept, the lead developer upped and left, and a noticeably large chunk of the playerbase has died off due to boredom. It feels like a lot of drive and inspiration has been lost and Three Rings thinks it can fill this void with shiny new" reskins and repeating event content and hope that no one notices while they try to piece everything back together behind the scenes
date: IF they're trying to piece everything back together behind the scenes
recommended: maybe they aren't. It's been over a year now and there are STILL a bunch of unfixed problems and bugs related to the sprites update that was released just before everything fell apart.\n\nExamples: Some minerals have no purpose and get stuck in your inventory; sprites have a level numbering system that makes no sense

reviewText:
Good game, however, the energy system is the worst free to play system I've ever seen in a game, basically you can play for free, but you can't do anything without energy which you need to buy. 100 Mist energy is the maximum energy a free to play account has which equals to five quests. Mist energy regenerates 1 energy each 13 minutes. The worst part being that if you die in a quest(instance) you need energy to revive, if you don't spend that energy, you go back to town and that 20 mist energy you paid for the quest, is now gone and you made 0 progress within the game. And if you buy crystal energy (the one that doesn't regenerate) you have only what you've paid for. I'd rather pay 50 bucks and play forever (until a DLC/expansion comes out). And don't tell me that this game is worth more than 50 bucks because it isn't. If I want to play something worth my money I would rather choose something like Guild Wars 2.
Good things about this game? The co-op is very enjoyable, the ranking system is fun, the arcade system is basically an (almost) endless mode of instances and crafting could be better, a little complexity here and there won't hurt.
Rating (from someone you don't know/care about) = 5/10.
Hell, not enough energy to rate higher. Sorry.

reviewText:
Even though I am an older player when the game first ever came out, years ago, I'm going to bias this review upon it's current state, rather than babbling on what was better etc.

Pros:
~Entire game from start to finish is not blocked by a pay wall and is free, for those who actually can work for their gear, it's actually quite easy.

~For a java based game, the graphics are heavy and nice when maxed out, and there are even 16X AA options along with cull transients and effect rendering for faster CPUs.

~The combat system is very balanced and easy to pick up while also familiar to that of older retro games with the convenience of online play, with all of your friends.

~Battle sprite pets make great companions to the game, and there are 3 different types to choose from, with the option to have as many as you want, building their skills as you go up in the game.

~Vanity in this game is as refined as TF2's costume system, heavily impacting the market, and with the great art designers, I would say the costumes and accessories and possibilities of vanity in the game are awfully full of variety, and more so for end-gamers with more crowns to spare, and the designs on their own look very well worked and taken into consideration by the game's lead art designer.

~The game can offer optional challenging difficulties and has a variety of monsters to fight, as well as Danger rooms found randomly in arcade runs, and Danger missions which tend to strain player skills with high density monster battles and emphasis on either status resist and defense, or dragging a player's dodging skills and giving large consequences should they make any mistakes, in say a low defense set like the chaos set. Many ways to play yet simplistic.

~Game community is very good and still better compared to other MMO's I have personally seen, and guilds and their halls are greatly refined to freshen up the experience for many players, and coax guilds to work together to build their halls to great lengths and maintaining upkeep, and working towards boss statues later on as they grow.

Cons:

~Player controlled economy maintains the idea that more or less than half the player base will pay real money for the in game commodity, Crystal Energy, and will push it into the market for free to play players to buy with their earned crowns, now the problem in this is, that, the company, Three Rings entertainment, doesn't directly control the market and instead uses risky marketing methods, such as flash sales, promotions, prize boxes, and auction house featured flagship items and accessories and more, in hopes that players will buy more Crystal energy to obtain such things, which I think is not a bad marketing technique, but that would technically mean the game isn't entire Free for the whole player base, whether they spend or not, so in order to have energy, someone, somewhere in this game has to spent money and put it up on the market, so that the free player may obtain the same resource for free without real life money and instead in game goods. I call it a con because the economy is unstable and needs to be deflated at times, but as long as Three Rings can keep the market from inflating too much, I suppose this isn't such a big matter, but as I say with thus being said, this game isn't free for everyone.

~Players who prefer to be solo in the game may not get such a refined experience and may not play this game much considering the game itself doesn't offer too much for single player features, and reasons to stay in the game, some MMO's can be done entirely single, but the level design is too simplistic just for one player to analyze and enjoy long term, as there are certain limitations in place.

~Updates are quite slow due to the small development team, and there isn't really a whole lot of content for end gamers to enjoy, thus making the community solely keep some players from quitting because of the theoretical experience of playing with others making it more enjoyable.

Final Verdict:

~Play this game, see how you like it, it has a great lore that keeps theories coming almost like FnaF (though not as much lol) there are guilds, and still quite a bit of good mannered players and potential friends to make here, and the combat system while only having 3 types of technical weapon classes and sprite types, yet the large arsenal available allows anyone to create their own style of playing, silly or serious, or just something to do the job.

7/10 Satisfactory

reviewText:
Spiral Knights is a hack 'n' slash style MMORPG that feels much like a top-down Zelda game, complete with pots.The paid content, which is obtained through the game's premium currency, energy, is completely optional and for the most part, out of the way. You don't have to get it but it feels nicer to have it, especially in times where it's tough.

However, do not expect to get through the game with owning one set of armor and weapons at a time. Certainplaces contain certain enemies and hazards that may make you weaker or stronger depending on your gear, and playing with friends is often a must.

It may seem at first that you don't have to put much effort into fighing, but you have to pay attention to your enemies and their projectiles. Glowing areas on the ground indicate where an enemy is going to attack, but you need to act quickly to dodge it. Projectiles need to be watched for, and may sometimes come to you a-la bullet hell games.

My only complaints are that you cannot equip many weapons at one time and to do that you have to rent, let me repeat myself, RENT, extra slots to equip more items. Often you have to resort to getting things from the community marketplace because getting them from stages can be a chore and often shops won't have what you need, thus having to deal with the sometimes ludicrous prices of greedy players.

And on a final note you will have these things called Sparks of Life. You can use them when you die more than once or use them on fallen teammates who also died more than once. However as a word of caution, use them sparingly, as they're hard to come by through normal gameplay, but can be bought with energy, which in my opinion, sparks are the stuff you should buy the most, because, if you're struggling on a level and you don't have them, you're screwed.

reviewText:
Spiral Knights is really fun as you're progressing through the mission system. The gameplay is nice, the controls are simple, and the stat system is understandable. Three Rings puts heavy emphasis on co-op play, and it is certainly far more fun with more people.

Problem is, Three Rings updates the game slower than molasses going uphill in January with crutches. The only thing that can keep you hooked to the game is a desire(and the money) to do the Shadow Lairs, or a desire to play PvP and the money to be able to do buttshit in it. The only thing that can diversify equipment is a random Unique Variant system, and if you don't have the luck or money to get the best UVs, you might as well not play PvP at all.

Still, Spiral Knights is amazing for a F2P. Just don't get overaddicted to it like I did, because once you hit the endgame, you'll be there with nothing to do for a month.

reviewText:
Background ethos: I have a playtime of 55:07:28:52, linked is an alt account. I've been a customer of OOO since 2007. I 'jumped ship' from Y!PP to this game in 2012.

This game is a hard sell. It is fun, vibrant and is both simple enough to pick up, and compelling enough to not put down. 2 years ago, I would say that once you get over the mist system, it's an excellent game I hope to see grow to be even better.
2 years later, I cannot reccommend this game wholeheartily due to the missteps it has taken. There is no getting past the top-heavy 'first act' of the game, restricting leveling system, redundancy-by-proxy mission system, and lack of an endgame.
These decisions and the overall lack of content to explore being added in any fashion sour the game experience for me. While the game remains something I come back to, I can no longer tell my friends to try it out, and I won't tell you, reader, either.

reviewText: I do not play MMORPGs, so it's special when I say I play Spiral Knights. It's kept extremely simple, which makes it a great casual game that I can pick up and drop off without intense involvement. This is a good pizza-and-mouse game, meaning you can play one-handed due to the simplicity of the controls. It's a nice, calm, relaxing game, with stretches of tension and frustration. It's FtP, so there's limits on how much you can do in a 24 hour span, which kind of helps keeps me from seeing the limitations of the campaign missions. The skirmish missions are always different, but to clear a campaign, you must fight the same enemies on the same map. It has a difficulty spike in some areas. I love the visual design, and the music is an awesome combination of eight-bit and chill. Some of the collecting and trading aspects are difficult, as it isn't always easy to find someone who will buy what you want, even though it is extremely easy to buy items from others at the sub-ten tiers.  8.5/10.

reviewText:
If you live in a country far away from where the servers are located, this game would be perfect for testing your patience and anger management.
* Think you dodged a rocket? Think again...
* Think you blocked an attack with your sheild? Nope.
* Jumped out of the way to evade an attack? Too slow!
* Think you switched your weapon? Let me use the first weapon for you!
* Ran over retracted spiked floor? Nope, let me take some life off you for good measure
* Finished your 2 strike combo attack? Let me repeat that last swing for you so you can get hit during the animation while not doing any damage to the monsters!
* Have a personal ADSL2+ connection that averages 11.5Mbps and have thrown money at the game? Thanks, we will gladly take your money, here have some extra lag.
But that is ok because if you die, you can use spark items to revive. Ran out of life sparks? Sure, no problem! The in game shop has plenty for sale for real money!

reviewText:
Spiral knights is a game that I never thought would be this good. It's set up in a very interesting artificial world whose characteristics blend perfectly with the game features. The spiral knights (players), are newcomers to this world and are so far limited to a small section of the surface. Because of this, they need to explore its depths in to improve the toehold they have on it.

There are two main resources in spiral knights: crowns, which are the game's form of currency, and energy which is needed to activate the elevators and doors which allow the player to explore the world, as well as crafting all kinds of gear. While crowns are dropped by defeated enemies, energy can only gained by the pass of time (called mist energy and limited to 100 per account), purchased from other players using crowns (in the form of energy crystals), or purchased using real money.

Access to energy is the main difference between paying and free customers, but thanks to the inclusion of an energy market in the game's currency, free players can enjoy all the features the game has to offer though more slowly than paying customers.

So far I have been playing the game for free, and I'm having a blast. I also appreciate that the game is so friendly towards free customers (specially those who are too busy and cannot spend more than a couple of hours playing every day). Most likely I will start spending real money as I go further down the game, but for the moment I'm perfectly fine with the free version. This is a game I would definitely recommend you give it a go.

reviewText:
Hey fellow reader who is reading this review, I shall not bombard you with lots of information and such, but just simply shorty and quickly tell you about this game.
This game is fun if you are out there to grind for maybe 2 hours a day for maybe 2 months to be able to get your wished armor, which at the end might not be the recommended for the game, but who ******* cares.
I used to play this game to get the best armour and the best weapons and stuff, but as it has been going on and on, well... Let's just say that the game has passed from getting your so wished armour into trying to look cool because yes, now you don't grind for the 5* armour, you will grind for the ideal costume, believe me, It has become into that.
Now looking into the Pay to win aspect, which is not totally wrong, you may pay and instantly skip to get that 5*armour and...
you know what I went and just said so much usless information, For the real point, if you hav someone to play with it is quite atractive and fun, but otherwise playing alone, nope that time has been long gone, solo playing was good before. Now I'd solely recomend to play with friends, beside a good part of the community are good persons. If you do decide to play solo simply find a good guild and I believe you might enjoy the game.
On the other hand there are some unobtainable achievments in the game, they should fix that cause those were old achievments from when the game had those capabilities.

reviewText: Spiral Knights is, as I like to call it, a cutesy dungeon crawler". The game takes place in various depths of a mechanical planet that is always shifting and changing. With very easy to understand gameplay and lots of replayability

hoursPlayed: and bomb things with your friends.\n\nTHE GOOD Easy to learn
voteText:
but many advanced fighting tactics.
It's free!
Ever-changing and randomized dungeons in the Arcade!
Everything you need is achieveable in-game without paying up. Paying is purely for cosmetics
helpfulPercent: or to speed up the grind a bit.\nMarket and player trading. Trade items on the auction house
votesHelpful: sell or buy premium currency with your in-game earned money
votesTotal: or trade for either between players. You can even trade items with other players on Steam!\nIn-depth story
votesFunny: along with various mini-stories throughout the game. Lot of lore to get invested in!\nWeakness and resistance systems.\nLots of weapons
commentsCount: armors
column16:
and shields for you to craft or purchase from others!
A silly chat filter that can be disabled if you so please.
A startlingly vast cosmetic system with costume appearances and accessories to let you customize yourself.
Two PvP gamemodes - control points and bomberman.
Rotating events with unique rewards!
Unique Variants of gear that you can get as a bonus for crafting that allow for your gear to get super powerful!

reviewText: So much potential. Spiral Knights, in its early days, was a great MMORPG-ish thing with sensical mechanics and easy-to-learn gameplay. It was a great time-burner, trying to get all 5 star gear, running the Firestorm Citadel over and over. Unfortunately, as time passed, things took a turn for the worse. As OOO (or sega or whoever makes updates for this thing now) became more and more ambitious, the updates spiraled off and off into a sense of bleh. Missions were cool. Crimson Hammer was cool. Battle Sprites were cool. Mist energy being removed was passable. Being forced most of the time to spend $20 to upgrade a single piece of gear is not cool. At the advent of the Forge update, the game, while always being sort of a cash grab, became impossible to play. To get decently tiered gear now, you must slave away in T3, because the drops needed almost never actually drop. This has caused many of my friends who I knew to be seasoned veterans of the game to quit. The guild I was in, which had over 50 active players, went inactive a month after the update. Before the update with the Forge, pretty cool. After, not so much.

reviewText:
I must say after a couple hundred hours playing this deal, I have to say its a fun game, its a free to play with micro transactions, this is true, BUT its not completely HINGED on it, people can buy items from other people, hell even the DLC with just in game currency, its pretty good balance wise and missions are pretty much the same, get point A to point be and smack things between them, but it keeps the monsters diverse and adds a wide array of effects.

With thousands of weapons and armor choices to choose from you have full customizablity for your player, of course with some limitations because of the F2P-P2P gap, but as I said before this is breachable with LOTS of grinding, I mean its an MMO what do you expect? community is nice for the most part and are willing to help others out if they need it, at least from my experience.

Theres a lot to say for this game but in all honesty its 1 in the morning and I am too tired and chilled to really think too straight, so heres the run down version. Its fun, simple enough for new players yet complex enough to keep it interesting, people who are P2P aren't going to have a MASSIVE advantage over people who aren't which is fantastic in my book, at times it gets samey and grindy but its an MMO so its kinda forgivable, all the customization and effects on the hundreds of weapons adds for diverse play, so all in all I rate this a 8/10, I think it needs a better campaign and more PVP options but all in all its incredible for a F2P game.

but what the hell do I know, I spend 200+ hours staring at a screen smacking moving pink jello till one of us dies

reviewText:
So Spiral Knights... I played back in ye olde days before the steam release. For quite a while actually. months of playtime, possibly half a year. I went through the hell that was the CANT LOG IN phase in the game, stopping me from playing for a couple of weeks, which really killed me. That event seriously injured the game, and if I remember, wasa caused by some hacking over at Sega (but dont quote me on that). This little paragraph was just a backstory to what I've been through with this game, just to let you know that I LOVE this game, or atleast used to more than I do now, so the actual review is down below...
One last thing, I have not played this game in over a year, but I've looked at the update logs and such, so I atleast know what's happened.

Alright, the pros of this game. The gameplay itself is basic, but not mind-numbingly boring. You move around, attack, pick things up, dodge, etc. Better than most MMO's today, with all that clicking on something to blindly attack whatever bull. The art style of the game is quite nice. The soundtrack...boy, I REALLY like the soundtrack, one of my favorite things about this game. The community (in-game, why this is will be said later...) is probably one of the best things about this game. I made many in-game friends playing this game, some in particular were very nice and cool. And as I see in other reviews, Im not alone. The shop that drives the economy is the auction house, where you can put things up for crowns (currency). There are npc vendors, but I'll be honest, no one uses them, unless they have something unique.

Alright, now the bad stuff, the stuff I really hate to see. In the old days of Spiral Knights, there was mist energy. It regenerated quite slowly up to a maximum of 100. Elevators in the game were used to continue on through the levels, but cost 10 energy to use. So that's basically 10 levels a day, maybe around 12 if you use it at specific times. Crystal energy is considered the premium currency in this game, since every f2p game ever has to have one. But on one fateful day, mist energy was removed, but elevators are now free to use. This was a very smart decision, I thought, except when the rest of the update was revealed. Originally, to craft things, pretty much the only way to get high tier gear, you used energy and materials dropped from enemies. You would also pick up heat for your gear, which is used to level it up and make it better. But then, they added Orbs of Alchmey and Fire Shards. Orbs weren't that awful for me, but only because the game requires you to have a certain level weapon in order to craft the next tier of weapon. With the new fire shards, you had to have a specific fire shard, and depending on the amount you used, would show a percentage that the heat level up would be succesful. So you had to have lady luck on your side unless you want to potentially waste all your crystals on one of 10 heat levels (the max). Basically, the game became a grindfest for orbs and shards (and I didnt mention that lower grade shards cant be combined to make bigger shards, but bigger shards can be smashed into smaller ones. BUT you had to have the recipe to do that, which was given to you when you completed the gear check once you had all the same tier gear. Ex: Full tier 4 gear check, you go through, you can now get tier 5 gear. You get a recipe for smashing tier 5 shards, the ones you need, for tier 4 shards, the ones you USED to need. The system is very broken, and I dont think its changed at all.)
Before missions, there was the arcade, a place where gateways led to branches of levels, and players could influence which levels showed up in next weeks gates. This was were you went to actually PLAY the game. That always struck me as interesting. But when the missions came out, you could just skip all those levels and go straight to the boss levels, the main reason people were going down certain gates. Sure, it saved time and wasnt as much as a pain to get there, but missions literally KILLED the arcade. I dont see anyone there anymore, even though it still exists. I just feel it takes some exploration out of the game.
But what about the crystals? Now they're used for feeding your pet, which you get through a line of missions. Everyone freaked out at this since every MMO must ALWAYS have pets. When they came out, you could choose a mini dragon that shoots fire, a phantom ghost that shot out caustic needles and could go invisible, and a cat. You know, just a  cat that flies around. Guess which one no one ever picked...(the cat). Thing is, once I got my pet, I used him some, leveled him up a bit, but I always forgot about him. I never used him as often as he was intended, even though when I did remember him, he did help some. Doesn't this show that we have come to not need pets? We played the game to work as a team of knights traversing through the unknown depths of an alien planet, cut off from the rest of our home. Now its more like pet simulator.
And last but CERTAINLY not least, the new updates. I looked at over 30 update logs within the past year or so. All but about 2 had ACTUAL content. The rest of them were just adding limited time reskins of cosmetics, that cost money to get. This is just sad...  this isnt tf2.

Ok, so I sound like I dont like this game right? Well, I dont like what its become. I liked it before, (except for the elevators becoming free, that was the best thing ever) where it was actually different from other games. Like I said, I love this game, and I hate to see it die like this.

TL;DR (because i'll be honest, this review is frickin long) The game is fun, enjoyable, and all around a cool experience, although its taken some turns for the worst. I wouldnt want to see this game die, since it seems to be bleeding out right now. But overall I give this game a 7/10, or if nostalgia is added to the equation, 8/10. This game is a fantastic f2p, and I recommend it to anyone who is willing to try it out. Do note that the bad things kick in later in the game. You can enjoy the game starting out up til then.
Thank you for reading, and I hope you enjoy Spiral Knights.

reviewText:
Fun?  Yes.

Grindy?  Yes.

Better with friends?  Yeah.

Spiral Knights is a MMORPG which came out of the gate rocky, being like most korean mmo's where it was more 'pay to win'
Thankfully they fixed that.  So the game is pritty fun but it gets repeditive even with the shifting floors, and it never felt like it made and impact.

But i do indeed love the pet system.  It was fun to have a little battle pet fighting alongside you as you delved down with others to fight hoards of monsters ready to eat you.

Hey, its free to play, give it a shot, cant say its a bad game just grindy and kind of repeditive.

reviewText:
This game is probably my second favorite game of all time. The gameply is in stages cartoony fun monsters while you play a cartoony fun character.

The game does get a bit grindy with 'orbs' if you dont want to pay money to get past having to try and get a bunch of rare rare orb drops so that you can get the higher teir armor. But in my opinion, the grinding is the best part because it makes you get better at the game.

The bosses are definetly challenging for the tiers. (except for the first one)

This game has very great gameplay up until you beat the game/get everything you want in the game. They havent really made anything to do afterwards, just a dress up RPG and look cool and maybe manage a guild

Over all I give this game a ★★★★☆, I highly recommend this game.

reviewText: Spiral Knights is a cooperative hack and slash with a distinctly cute visual style, interesting lore, and a character customization system that continues to improve. reviewText:
Band together and fight to the Core!
Spiral Knights is a cooperative adventure in a persistent world with a focus on instant, fast-paced action. Arm yourself and join the ranks of the Spiral Knights; stranded on an alien world, they must explore the ever-changing Clockworks beneath its surface in hopes of reaching its mysterious Core.
Key Features
Co-operative Exploration
The Clockworks offer challenges that are best tackled with friends.
Fight monsters, solve puzzles and discover treasures together!
Instant Action
Go from login to a multiplayer adventure in less than a minute.
Ever-changing World
The Clockworks cycle levels to explore in real time. Every moment of every day changes the world.
Create an Arsenal
There are hundreds of unique weapons and gear to discover and alchemize.
Form Powerful Guilds
Guild alliances allow greater influence over the world. Amass powerful minerals to transform the Clockworks!
Free to Play!
Spiral Knights is free to play, no subscription is required to enjoy everything the game has to offer.

reviewText:
So Spiral Knights... I played back in ye olde days before the steam release. For quite a while actually. months of playtime, possibly half a year. I went through the hell that was the CANT LOG IN phase in the game, stopping me from playing for a couple of weeks, which really killed me. That event seriously injured the game, and if I remember, wasa caused by some hacking over at Sega (but dont quote me on that). This little paragraph was just a backstory to what I've been through with this game, just to let you know that I LOVE this game, or atleast used to more than I do now, so the actual review is down below...
One last thing, I have not played this game in over a year, but I've looked at the update logs and such, so I atleast know what's happened.

Alright, the pros of this game. The gameplay itself is basic, but not mind-numbingly boring. You move around, attack, pick things up, dodge, etc. Better than most MMO's today, with all that clicking on something to blindly attack whatever bull. The art style of the game is quite nice. The soundtrack...boy, I REALLY like the soundtrack, one of my favorite things about this game. The community (in-game, why this is will be said later...) is probably one of the best things about this game. I made many in-game friends playing this game, some in particular were very nice and cool. And as I see in other reviews, Im not alone. The shop that drives the economy is the auction house, where you can put things up for crowns (currency). There are npc vendors, but I'll be honest, no one uses them, unless they have something unique.

Alright, now the bad stuff, the stuff I really hate to see. In the old days of Spiral Knights, there was mist energy. It regenerated quite slowly up to a maximum of 100. Elevators in the game were used to continue on through the levels, but cost 10 energy to use. So that's basically 10 levels a day, maybe around 12 if you use it at specific times. Crystal energy is considered the premium currency in this game, since every f2p game ever has to have one. But on one fateful day, mist energy was removed, but elevators are now free to use. This was a very smart decision, I thought, except when the rest of the update was revealed. Originally, to craft things, pretty much the only way to get high tier gear, you used energy and materials dropped from enemies. You would also pick up heat for your gear, which is used to level it up and make it better. But then, they added Orbs of Alchmey and Fire Shards. Orbs weren't that awful for me, but only because the game requires you to have a certain level weapon in order to craft the next tier of weapon. With the new fire shards, you had to have a specific fire shard, and depending on the amount you used, would show a percentage that the heat level up would be succesful. So you had to have lady luck on your side unless you want to potentially waste all your crystals on one of 10 heat levels (the max). Basically, the game became a grindfest for orbs and shards (and I didnt mention that lower grade shards cant be combined to make bigger shards, but bigger shards can be smashed into smaller ones. BUT you had to have the recipe to do that, which was given to you when you completed the gear check once you had all the same tier gear. Ex: Full tier 4 gear check, you go through, you can now get tier 5 gear. You get a recipe for smashing tier 5 shards, the ones you need, for tier 4 shards, the ones you USED to need. The system is very broken, and I dont think its changed at all.)
Before missions, there was the arcade, a place where gateways led to branches of levels, and players could influence which levels showed up in next weeks gates. This was were you went to actually PLAY the game. That always struck me as interesting. But when the missions came out, you could just skip all those levels and go straight to the boss levels, the main reason people were going down certain gates. Sure, it saved time and wasnt as much as a pain to get there, but missions literally KILLED the arcade. I dont see anyone there anymore, even though it still exists. I just feel it takes some exploration out of the game.
But what about the crystals? Now they're used for feeding your pet, which you get through a line of missions. Everyone freaked out at this since every MMO must ALWAYS have pets. When they came out, you could choose a mini dragon that shoots fire, a phantom ghost that shot out caustic needles and could go invisible, and a cat. You know, just a  cat that flies around. Guess which one no one ever picked...(the cat). Thing is, once I got my pet, I used him some, leveled him up a bit, but I always forgot about him. I never used him as often as he was intended, even though when I did remember him, he did help some. Doesn't this show that we have come to not need pets? We played the game to work as a team of knights traversing through the unknown depths of an alien planet, cut off from the rest of our home. Now its more like pet simulator.
And last but CERTAINLY not least, the new updates. I looked at over 30 update logs within the past year or so. All but about 2 had ACTUAL content. The rest of them were just adding limited time reskins of cosmetics, that cost money to get. This is just sad...  this isnt tf2.

Ok, so I sound like I dont like this game right? Well, I dont like what its become. I liked it before, (except for the elevators becoming free, that was the best thing ever) where it was actually different from other games. Like I said, I love this game, and I hate to see it die like this.

TL;DR (because i'll be honest, this review is frickin long) The game is fun, enjoyable, and all around a cool experience, although its taken some turns for the worst. I wouldnt want to see this game die, since it seems to be bleeding out right now. But overall I give this game a 7/10, or if nostalgia is added to the equation, 8/10. This game is a fantastic f2p, and I recommend it to anyone who is willing to try it out. Do note that the bad things kick in later in the game. You can enjoy the game starting out up til then.
Thank you for reading, and I hope you enjoy Spiral Knights.

Missions typically involve you progressing through a dungeon littered with enemies and different types of square voxels of differing types (ex: wall voxel or explosive voxel). reviewText: Spiral Knights is a throw back to old school action rpg platformers, and in my opinion is most similar to the Zelda franchise (Zelda 4 swords adventure in particular). The core gameplay is casual but also fun and addictive. The graphics, while certainly nothing to brag about, are more than adequate to provide a smooth gaming experience while not looking too outdated. The music is both melodic and reminiscent of the good old 8bit days. There are some minor lag problems due to the games use of UDP protocols and because of the limmited server size, however, the game is still in ongoing development and there's no reason to think these issues won't be rectified in the future. All in all I'd recommend Spiral Knights to anyone and give it a 4/5 rating.

reviewText: I do not play MMORPGs, so it's special when I say I play Spiral Knights. It's kept extremely simple, which makes it a great casual game that I can pick up and drop off without intense involvement. This is a good pizza-and-mouse game, meaning you can play one-handed due to the simplicity of the controls. It's a nice, calm, relaxing game, with stretches of tension and frustration. It's FtP, so there's limits on how much you can do in a 24 hour span, which kind of helps keeps me from seeing the limitations of the campaign missions. The skirmish missions are always different, but to clear a campaign, you must fight the same enemies on the same map. It has a difficulty spike in some areas. I love the visual design, and the music is an awesome combination of eight-bit and chill. Some of the collecting and trading aspects are difficult, as it isn't always easy to find someone who will buy what you want, even though it is extremely easy to buy items from others at the sub-ten tiers.  8.5/10.
